What is so good about this game? I really love fixing stuff up around the house, but it's a lot of work and expensive to boot. Now I can simply click a button and do exactly the same thing without the hassle, mess or costs.

After all these years I left a review, because I couldn't get into the game. It made me realize how much I miss it, even though I start it up occasionally, it's always great. So, now that it's been solved, why not change it to a big fat "yes".

Also, it can be terrifying once you notice it. Notice what, you ask? There's nobody in the streets! You only see people on your tablet. In my headcannon my character is the only one alive and he keeps himself busy with renovating houses and talking to AI just to keep his sanity.

pros:

1: some houses also have Easter eggs or are based on TV/Movie/Anime houses which is fun in its own way.

4: you can turn day/night mod off

cons:

4: music is a bit boring, though it is calming. would had loved to have rock or jazz music to work with!

I have a lot of things to say but ill keep it as short as i can~

Pros:
-so much fun doing all the jobs
-i love that CAT POSTERS!
-you can add your own photos to the house
-easy once you know what youre doing
-lots of decorating options

Cons:
-the Cockroaches are difficult to suck up. (also theyre so nasty and they make my skin crawl. just get in the vacuum sooner please.)
-some of the items dont go where i want them. the invisible barrier is a pain.
-i get stuck on random things sometimes
-that one spec of dirt you cant find? yea, its gonna haunt you.
-the spider webs dont show up map even if you have all the perks unlocked.
-lawn mowing isnt apartment of the base game and i hate looking at the grass all unruly. so i bought the DLC.

DLC Pets Pros:
-CATSSSSSS
-i love giving the cats pets all the time when i see them.
-theyre so cute even when theyre coughing hairballs on my rug.
-you can have as many pets as your computer can handle.
-you can get a pet hotel so you can have even more pets in a separate area. (the hotel is just another house btw)
-SNAKES! <3
-CAAAAAAAATS
-did i mention cats?
-Cats <3
-all the pet stuff is sooooo cute

DLC Pets Cons:
-the cats can get stuck under chairs and then get hungry and you dont notice till you see a yellow paw on your map and you start freaking out cuz ohno your baby is suffering what do i do?! so you delete the chair and manually pick up your cat to put her infront of the food only for her to run away and you chase her all over the house but no, Pancake doesnt wanna eat even though shes hungry. so you have to buy the chair back and hope she doesnt get stuck underneath the chair again. but oh look. she does.
-i demand more cat breeds. EX: MANX

DLC Gardener Pros:
-Pretty
-love cutting the grass
-pick them weeds! hell yea. pop pop pop!
-pretty flowers and stuff
-still love cutting the grass

DLC Gardener Cons:
-you cant put the plants closer together and it looks so grid like and i dont like how they look and i want them to be closer but they cant. :{
-i get stuck on plants more often then i care to admit
-theres some weeds stuck in some objects from basegame that i you cant just buy back? unless i havent found it yet. 

Overall 7.5/10

Literally so disappointed. I was so hyped to try this game, but it ended up being so buggy to the point where it was unplayable. First, before even playing the game, the menus had multiple instances of places where images were supposed to be, but instead there were blank white boxes. Then when I started playing, I noticed in the shed, one of what I assumed to be a poster was just a flat magenta rectangle. Once into the tutorial, there were multiple other pieces of trash just completely magenta with zero graphics. Now all that I could overlook, but then when the game suggests you open your tablet whether to buy a radiator, or to pick a skill point, the whole game fails. I press the tab button to open the tablet, and it does not open, but does effectively freeze the game. I try to put the invisible tablet away, and now wasd doesn't work, nor does any other movement. Then when trying to reopen the invisible tablet, the game tells me I can't. I then have to force close the game because esc doesn't work after trying to use the invisible tablet. I've tried uninstalling, I've tried restarting multiple times in multiple saves, I've tried changing the controls so the tablet button is a different button. Nothing works. Completely nonfunctional.

house flipper is a simulation game developed by empyrean and published by frozen district & playway. it released in 2018 for pc & 2020 for ps4, xbox one, nintendo switch, & mobile devices. it's garnered significant attention for its unique premise and addictive/satisfying gameplay, while at the same time leaving players questioning its long-term playability. you step into the shoes of a one-person renovation crew, tasked with buying, renovating, and selling properties for profit. the game blends elements of strategy, creativity, and time management, offering players a truly immersive experience in the world of home renovation. 

at its core, house flipper offers a simple yet engaging gameplay loop: acquire properties, clean and renovate them, and then sell for profit. however, the depth of customization and attention to detail elevate this seemingly straightforward concept into a rich and rewarding experience. players start small, taking on humble jobs such as cleaning up abandoned properties, fixing broken appliances, and repainting walls. as they progress, they gain access to more advanced renovation tools and can tackle larger projects, including complete home makeovers.

the game's mechanics are intuitive and easy to grasp, even for players unfamiliar with the intricacies of home renovation. the user interface is clean and well-designed, with helpful tooltips and tutorials guiding players through each step of the process. from hammering nails to installing light fixtures, every action feels satisfying and impactful, thanks to the game's semi-realistic physics engine. one of the standout features of house flipper is its extensive array of renovation options. players can choose from a wide selection of furniture, appliances, and decorations to personalize each property according to their tastes. whether you prefer a minimalist aesthetic or a cozy, rustic vibe, the game offers enough variety to cater to every design sensibility. the ability to experiment with different layouts and color schemes adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay, encouraging players to unleash their creativity and design skills.

there's a certain satisfaction in taking a gross & dirty room and making it look nice, and it's pretty cool that you can knock down (and rebuild) walls, but i just don't find the act of slowly painting and cleaning much fun, despite my playtime potentially suggesting otherwise.

However...
You may have to spend hours tweaking with the settings to get the best consistent performance before starting to play the actual game (including setting up specific settings in your graphics card app to ensure the game will run as smoothly as possible), regardless of your setup. This is beause your hardware may be bottlenecking without those tweaks and so you will get low FPS when you feel you should be getting more.
Despite this little fact, I do still recommend the game to the communty.

So, let's talk about House Flipper – a game that's like a digital hug for all the budding virtual renovators out there. The graphics have this charming nostalgic vibe, kind of like revisiting your childhood game console. It's not exactly 4K, but hey, who needs hyper-realism when you can have a cozy, pixelated atmosphere?

Now, the gameplay is the virtual equivalent of a weekend home improvement project. It's got this comforting simplicity – you pick up your virtual tools and start transforming spaces. No pressure, just a laid-back experience. Whether you're fixing leaky faucets or giving a room a fresh coat of paint, it's oddly therapeutic.

Customization is where you get to sprinkle a bit of your personality into the virtual world. Sure, the furniture options may not rival a high-end design catalog, but there's a certain charm in creating spaces with the limited choices. It's like having a conversation with your virtual home, and it says, "Let's keep it simple and cozy."

The clients are a quirky bunch – they're not just homeowners; they're like your virtual companions on this renovation journey. Their feedback is, well, let's say "constructive," and it adds a touch of humanity to the process. You're not just fixing walls; you're making someone's virtual dream home.

The soundtrack is a gentle background melody – it's not trying to steal the show, just providing a soothing ambiance. It complements the overall experience, making you feel like you're in your own little creative bubble.

In a world of glitches, House Flipper has its share of quirks, but it's nothing major. It's like hanging out with a friend who occasionally forgets where they put their keys – a minor inconvenience that doesn't overshadow the fun.

So, to sum it up, House Flipper is like a cozy sweater for your gaming soul. It might not be the flashiest game on the block, but it offers a laid-back and heartwarming experience. It's not about the destination; it's about enjoying the journey of turning virtual chaos into a comforting digital haven.

I definitely recommend this game if you enjoy the idea of decorating and reno-ing.  There are a lot of frustrating things you need to work through, but it is addictive.
The GOOD 
- pretty good user interface, especially once everything is upgraded.  (Tip from someone who took a while to notice it, you don't aim your tool at the item, you aim the microscopic white dot that blends in with light backgrounds)
- nice mix of jobs at the start, so you can earn money for the house purchases.
-Large catalogue of items, colors, furniture etc. and a search bar if you can't remember where you saw it, so long as you remember what it's called (no trash cans, just bins)
-Once every property has been sold once you can buy them again, in the original condition.
-variety of properties, from hut to castle
-I got the garden DLC and it was worth it,
- very active and helpful player community, usually pretty easy to find an answer or at least find someone to confirm "its not just you".
The BAD
- you can't do anything with the yard except weed whack unless you shell out for the garden DLC.  Not even mow the hideously overgrown yards at every property.
- the color palette is very inconsistent between sample, can, and wall.  Some supposedly light colors are almost neon.  The light you put in can change it entirely so I would say put in the light and turn them on before painting.
- It seems like 75% of the kitchen accessories and rugs are Christmas themed.  They are all at the top so you have to scroll through them every damn time.  The smaller rugs that would fit in a bathroom are just solid colored, textureless squares for the most part, look horribly out of place, and appear to have been thrown in as an afterthought.  
- Size descriptions are next to useless on decorations.  Some small pictures are mural sized, and other "large"
paintings are pretty little.  Be prepared to spend a lot of time trying to remember which sizes you need.
- drape type curtains are a pain in the ass.  Put them up before furnishing or they won't go up.  
- I wish there was more consistency with the patterns, I mean dozens of bed options but only one will have a certain bedding color/print.  And good luck remembering which of the curtain options actually has a match for the bedspread.  Pretty slapdash.
- The BUYERS all need to get hit by virtual trucks.  There are supposedly things you do to attract certain buyers but they don't seem to matter much.  No matter what you do, a house that is basically a giant pink sauna with two bathtubs, a giant bedroom, a huge closet, and no kitchen will still be "won" by the family who wants a kitchen and multiple bedrooms.  It's insanely frustrating.  And some of what they say they want are the same things they whine about.  This aspect of the game was very poorly designed.
- I find that the shopping is a bit tough because the contrast is so off that some stuff is literally invisible.  it's just so ridiculously white and I haven't found a way to fix it.  Every other thing on my computer is fine so it's not my settings.
- There is no eyedropper tool, so if you need to match something in the house it is a tedious project of going through each tile/panel in turn, and sometimes it turns out there is no match.  
- Some things have dozens of options and others have none.  Not sure why.
-Only way to get any cash from yards is to enter contests, which can have pretty tight requirements that the the fun out of making it your way if you want max return. (Eg the American garden seems to need one of each conifer, many of which look alike, so it becomes a tedious chore rather than a fun activity

The UGLY (As in blatantly lazy coding that has not been addressed despite many comments in the discussions)
- there are lovely  kitchen sets with lovely sinks.  Some of them the game does not recognize as sinks and thus will not call a room a kitchen.  So you have to either sell the set at a loss, or add another stupid sink.  There are a lot of newer items that do not register as what they are, meaning your beautiful bedroom might end up not being a bedroom.
- Some really basic stuff, like the lawnmower, requires a DLC purchases.
- Lately I've noticed you can't put things on the original window sills, though I could before.  You must sell the window, and then re-buy and install the window, even if it's the exact same window.  Only then can your plants sit in the sun on the window sill.  This is infuriating to me.  And I imagine the plants aren't thrilled either.
- The two young families try to buy EVERYTHING!  I mean, there is six of you.  Why the H are you still trying to buy the three room house I'm doing up for the misanthropic plant lady?  They really need to have a bit more separation between the buyers' needs.

Anyway, that's my take, most of it was easy to work around once I was aware it was an issue so hopefully this helps a bit.  Overall, a good game with lots to do.

This is, without a doubt, my favorite game on Steam. This is the game I go to when I have no mental energy to play a new game, or when I can’t work out what I’m meant to do next in the game I’m playing. This is my default game.

The story is fairly nonexistent, we have no backstory as a character other than we are a “do it all” handyperson. We repair, clean, demolish, build, paint, furnish, you name it we do it. We do odd jobs for people who email us, and as we earn money we can eventually buy houses and flip them for profit. It’s extremely enjoyable, as long as you enjoy that kind of repetitive gameplay that only differs in the details.

You also have the Steam Workshop, where you can download custom furniture made by other players, and that is what separates the game from any other simulation game for me. Being able to not only build and customize your own house, but do so with custom furniture as well, it brings it to a level only Sims has ever reached for me, but this is purely the construction part of Sims and that’s all I’ve ever wanted in life.

That said, you really do need the DLC packs to enjoy the game to the fullest, as a lot of the best tools and abilities are only available in specific DLC packs. For example, the ability to fully construct your own home from scratch is only available in Farm DLC, you cannot do that in the base game or any of the previous DLCs. 

I would recommend, if you’re interested, put the game on your wishlist and wait for a sale as you can often get the entire bundle for 20-40% off if you wait. That said, if you have the funds please do buy it at full price and support the developers, the game really is worth it.

Love it! Probably one of my favorite games. As someone who is very confused by the Sims 4 building mechanics but loves to be able to customize and build my own things this is a great choice! I just had to get the DLC's (especially the pets, I love them all) they are a great addition to the game, I love that they are technically a different game mode and unlock some nice items you can use in your own office or when selling a house. 

I also enjoy the fact that even in the base game (or DLC's) you still get some creative freedom when making over someones place, two or three choices for paint or tiles, or even just being able to choose what color scheme the furniture or items will have. Making the layout of rooms is probably one of the best and worst part of the game, its kinda like playing tetris, but I love it non-the less 

Cons? Only thing I'd have to mention is the lag, as I use my old beat up laptop to play games and this one happens to be a little hard on the old thing. Another thing I'd have to mention is installing things in game, mainly things such as a washer or windows, as the washer tends to clip you camera into the wall behind it leaving it in a weird angle as well, which makes it hard to pull parts in the directions they need to go. As for windows installation, when a house requires a window in a certain room I sometimes run into trouble with the checklist accepting it as a task being completed. I had to replace a window maybe 6 times in one home to get it to be fully recognized as a finished task.

Other than that, would definitely recommend for anyone into the chill and relaxing side of gaming.

[h1]Highly Recommend - 10/10[/h1]
House Flipper is a simulation game that lets you buy, renovate, and sell houses in various ways. I have been playing it for many years (and have 99 hours into this game at the time of writing this review) and I love the creative freedom and variety it offers. The game has different modes, such as missions, where you complete tasks for clients, and sandbox, where you can design your own dream house. The game also has several DLCs, such as Farm and Pets, that add new features and content. I enjoy both of these DLCs very much, as they enhance the game play and the immersion.

The game is not only fun, but also relaxing and satisfying. Its a great game to pick up after a hard day at work and unleash your creativity. There is something therapeutic about cleaning, painting, and decorating houses, and seeing the results of your hard work. The game also has a realistic and detailed graphics engine, which makes the houses and the environments look amazing. The game is constantly updated with new content and improvements, which keeps me interested and excited. I am eagerly look forward to playing House Flipper 2, which promises to be even better than the first one.

House Flipper is one of my favourite simulation games of all time, and I highly recommend it to anyone who likes home design and management. It is a game that combines challenge, fun, and beauty in a wonderful way.

I just wanted to drop a quick note about House Flipper because I'm absolutely loving it! If you've ever dreamed of being a one-person HGTV crew, this game is your ticket.

First off, the graphics are surprisingly crisp and clean. I didn't expect such attention to detail in a game where you're essentially cleaning up other people's messes, but it makes the whole experience way more immersive. It's weirdly satisfying to scrub away virtual grime and see a space transform right before your eyes.

The range of tasks you can do is mind-blowing. I started off just fixing leaky faucets and painting walls, but before I knew it, I was knocking down walls and redesigning entire rooms. The freedom to unleash your inner interior designer is so addictive – it's like The Sims on steroids.

And let's talk about the before-and-after moments. Seriously, if you're into that instant gratification of seeing a space go from disaster to dream home, this game delivers. Every completed project feels like a personal triumph, and I can't get enough of it.

The market aspect is a cool twist too. It adds a strategic layer to the game, making you think about what upgrades will give you the best return on investment. It's like Monopoly, but with power tools.

I've sunk way more hours into House Flipper than I care to admit, but honestly, it's time well spent. Whether you're into home improvement or just need a break from reality, this game is an absolute blast. Highly recommend giving it a shot!

This game is great! At first, it might seem a bit dull. That was what it looked like it might be at first for me, at least. And it was. Because when I first played it, the free update/farm DLC (I can't remember which one gives you it because I bought the farm DLC) wasn't out yet. That meant that you couldn't build houses, you could only renovate houses that we already built. But now. you can build from scratch. I highly recommend (even if the building wasn't in it) to buy the Farm DLC. It adds the interesting feature of being able to own farm animals and planting crops. That is extremely fun. Like I said, repeating myself now, I highly recommend that you buy the Farm DLC with House Flipper. The other fun thing with the Farm DLC is that you can milk the cows, milk the goats, collect eggs from the chickens, ride horses, and more interactions with animals like that. It's amazing! But, back to the base game itself, overall, it is a good game. Out of ten (without the Farm DLC), I'd rate it 8/10. With the Farm DLC, probably 10/10. You can't go wrong with buying House Flipper.
But there are some bad things in it. Here are some of them listed

1. You have to buy another DLC to make the game interesting
2. A bit pricey.
3. It does have the occasional bug, but nothing serious.
4. Without the extra DLC, (at least I find) the game is a bit boring. It gets repetitive. 

Other than that though, this game is perfect! A must buy, at very least. There seems to be something for everyone in it, a pet DLC for animal lovers, a Farm DLC to spicen the game up, a Garden DLC for people who love planting gardens, and more! If you love tidying houses, this is the game for you. 

HOW THE GAME WORKS

Basically, you'll get emails asking you to do jobs at houses. You can go to the house and do a bit of cleaning up. Usually, it will be things like broken wine glasses on the ground, water spillages everywhere, walls that need cleaning, and once everything to do with tidying up is done, you will most likely have to do something like put down some sofas, build some walls in the inside of the house to change the room layout, break down some walls, put up some pictures, put down a wardrobe, bed, and chest of drawers down in the bedroom e.t.c. Occasionally, you find cockroaches and have to hoover them up. This can be changed to small pieces of glass in settings though, and you get a warning in the first house with cockroaches in it. You also have to do some fixing work, for instance a plug socket might not be working quite right, and then you would fix it up. You do things like this in the house until it is completely done. Then you get your pay and you go home. After you have done this for quite a while (going to houses and doing work e.t.c.), you will have enough money to buy a house. When you have done this, you can have a look around, and renovate it with no restrictions. That is quite fun. But then you have the auction. That is even more fun. I'm not entirely sure, but I think that you can do other jobs whilst the people bid. But, if you are at the house, you will see the top bidders at the left side of your screen. One of them might say something like, "There's not enough bookshelves for all my books." and then you might place a couple bookshelves down and the person might place a higher bid. Once you have got a certain amount of point things for selling houses and that kind of thing, you can negotiate the price with people, for instance, if they had voted 3900 you could say 4000 and they might accept or refuse. You aren't guaranteed to have it accepted. Anyway, that's the most of the game. If you are reading this sentence, I congratulate you as this has turned into a long review.

for a 93% game on steam I guess I imagined something a bit more fleshed out.

I boot up the laptop, I do a mission, I get paid.
I make enough money to buy a house and I start cleaning it up, improving it and refurnishing it to re-sell it for a profit.
And that's about it.

What about having a realtor visit your house, and visibly point out the issues that could be changed.
What about being able to hire contractors to do the tiresome work instead of doing it all by yourself.
What about leveling up your skills to the point of not having to put every fu***** panel up manually, but just do it instantly for an entire wall if you wanted to.

The game really feels like a 'babies first video-game'.
Looking at the Empyrean List of Games, I can tell that my ideas are probably too far out for the development team.

But hey, maybe they'll add some more mechanics to the sequel! - [i]Oh wait...[/i]

House Flipper is a LOT of fun - though it would be hard to say exactly why. Maybe it appeals to the fantasy of owning property and modifying it however you want (which, even if it isn't, seems out of reach to many, including me). I've lost hours to cleaning, repairing, furnishing, and finally selling homes. It's a bit weird sometimes (yeah, I'll just sweep this couch clean of this suspicious stain real quick), but I can't complain about it *too* much. That said, there is some stuff I CAN complain about:

* Unhelpful or Vague Directions
    Most of this has been fixed with regular updates, which is great. However, when a new mechanic is introduced, it can be very difficult to figure out exactly what to do. I struggled for quite a while the first time repairing outlets was introduced, for instance. These mechanics are explained beyond a red marker on your minimap. A bit more tutorial - even just a pop-up message - when a new mechanic is introduced could go a long way.

* Alignment issues
    I have yet to get a dang door to line up just how I want, and that's with a good chunk of practice. It feels neigh impossible to achieve the same placement as the defaults, especially with the outer doors. This can make some homes feel not quite right.
    In addition, arranging furniture (in particular, the little decor objects like books and vases) can be an absolute mess to get where you want them. It's not as bad as, say, Skyrim, but it's still annoying.

* The Auction System
    Just a minor nitpick here. When you go to sell a house, it has to be sold to the highest bidder in an auction. I would really like to see a way to accept a lower bid. This might be a way to help add variety by intentionally renovating a house to the known preferences of a certain bidder.

* No outdoor actions
    Apart from cleaning and changing the siding of a home, no actions are allowed outside. It would be nice to be able to do some landscaping, add outdoor lighting, maybe a welcome mat, some furniture, and perhaps even change the porches/decks. In at least one home, I got rid of some damaged fencing along a porch and couldn't replace it. That was very frustrating.
    ** UPDATE**: The "Garden Flipper" DLC has been released, but that contains ALL outdoor functions. I don't mind adding a lot of functionality in paid content, but adding some basic stuff for free wouldn't go amiss.

* Lack of some choice
    There's a single shower for purchase and installation (despite several non-playable options), no color choice for some other parts (like electrical outlets and light switches), and an inability to color parts of some cabinets. This can limit the feel of more open rooms, like combination kitchen/dining/living rooms (UPDATE: A lot of this has been updated, with new options for outlets, baths/showers, etc. Even options to move plumbing, external doors, and windows - a very welcome addition!). Speaking of which...

* Room definition
    If I make a HUGE connected kitchen and living room, even with the nicest kitchen possible, the game acts the same as if I threw down a hotplate on a desk. It would be nice to get a little more sophisticated detection so buyers of the homes don't get so annoyed.

* Color previews - or lack thereof
    There are no paint color previews, and the wall color is ALWAYS darker than the color displayed in the store or in the can. Without a way to know what a color really looks like, this can lead to a lot of somewhat costly experimentation, or just a lot of bland painting.
    The same issue exists to a lesser extent with wall tiles. It can be hard to judge how a tile will look until it's already up, and tiling isn't the fastest or most fun minigame.

* Day/night cycle performance issues
    While the inclusion of the cycle is nice, nighttime brings a HUGE performance hit to my PC. I admit I'm rather graphically bound, but it's big enough I wanted to mention it. This cycle can be turned off (and honestly, I suggest you do - it's hard to judge paint color at night), however.

* Misc
    I have had color disappear from curtains in houses, leading to sadness.
    Cockroaches regenerate while exterminating - this can be really frustrating.
    Imperfect English translation (some awkward phrasing)
    Can't paint ceilings


So after that list, you may be wondering why I still recommend House Flipper. Simply put, if it's not on the list of complaints, that means it works really well. As noted above, I've seriously sunk hours at a time playing this game. It's far from perfect, but it's really enjoyable - and regular updates keep adding functionality, bug fixes, and quality-of-life improvements. Even for full price, this is worth it. If you like work simulators or want something a little more involved (but admittedly more restrictive) than The Sims, grab House Flipper.

It sounds like the most ridiculous thing - especially to people who don't really play video games - but this game and others like it (Powerwash Simulator, specifically) are remarkable tools for calming the mind. There's something extraordinary in how the simple processes involved in this game--cleaning, picking up trash, demolishing, etc--can help me not only wind down after a busy day, but also get me in the kind of "zen" focus zone that is conducive to helping me sleep quite well. 

And then there's the part of the game that sparks creativity and joy. I've long thought I would be a good house flipper, if only there wasn't so much physical labor involved. I also have long believed I'd be a good interior designer, because I have watched a lot of shows of that nature, so. Clearly I would be good at it. In all seriousness, though, the process of designing stuff in this game is not only creative, but adds to to the calming nature I mentioned before. Making sure everything is placed "just so," that colors match, that things are aligned and that spaces feel good...all of it leads to a general sense of well-being I just don't get from many other games. 

In summary, this is a good game.

The game is alright in short bursts I guess but it's ruined by some things. 

The awkward menu you use for searching for objects to buy for decorating and furnishing - there's no 'Did you mean this...' or anything. You either have to search for the exact name of the item or search through a whole page of things for one specific item. Very tedious and time consuming.  

For example, you can't simply type in 'shelf' or 'tv unit' or something like that (I can't remember exactly what I typed in) but nothing shows up - but there are actually shelves and tv units or cabinets or whatever. They just don't show up by searching using those words. 

The whole game pretty much relies on this menu for buying/decorating and it just sucks - it's not at all precise and just a pain in the ass. You also can't click back or open different tabs. I had to keep typing in the same query every time. It more than doubles the amount of time you're spending on browsing and selecting stuff from the catalogue.

I mean really it's just shit... Sims does it better. 

There's also the fact that almost every house you go to is identical and you can't even cut the grass without paying for an over priced DLC. In fact, most of the good stuff is locked behind DLC - including the really basic stuff that you would do anyway to make the house more presentable both inside and out (e.g. cutting the fucking grass). 

I think it's also a tad bit too basic overall... It's mostly just dealing with the shit menus and playing clicking simulator. Want to paint a wall? Buy paint, click paint, click wall, rinse and repeat. Pretty much everything is just click, click, clickity click. A bit mind numbing. The whole gameplay loop is! I like simulators but this isn't really proper. There's no thought required at all like with e.g. Bus Simulator/Farming Simulator or even Bakery Simulator or Thief Simulator! I suppose you can get creative but for what? I spent hours on a house and my reward was next to nothing. 

I know it's always more tempting to take the easy road and play something that doesn't require any thought whatsoever and you can just sit there drooling and wasting the day away instead of playing something with substance but this ain't it bro... And you don't want to support devs that charge you over £10 to cut the fucking grass! 

I got this game for like £1-£3 with two DLC too and that's about the right price for this I think. But from me it's a big fat NOPE. Also, the community is weird. Now don't get me wrong... I think this game could be worth it for people with autism maybe or OCD no cap but for the rest of you again: nope.

I can think of a few different things that would make the game a proper simulator and make it feel more alive like having the clients actually exist (actual NPCs) that perhaps come to view the property or being able to rent the property, collect rent, evict bad tenants and clean up afterwards for the next tenant or having to visit properties to make repairs. Also not having to appease a handful of cliches and instead allow you free reign to build, design and decorate the house as you see fit and sell it for a more realistic price or even less realistic if it means the game will actually respect your time (the time you've invested into the project - just add a few thousand £ on top) and so much more.

The base idea is definitely interesting. Cleanup and refurbish properties. The money you make doing it doesn't even matter, just the fact of making something that was a mess beautiful gives off serotonin.

The fact that you can do it in a game without having to put in the actual hours of work makes it seem like there is no way this could not be fun.

However in practice the experience gets very dull in a couple hours of gameplay. Mostly due to the fact that all these properties have the exact same type of trash to clean, the tasks feel monotonous. If houses were crafted with more unique dirt elements rather than copy pasted elements I could see this being so much more fulfilling.

I wish I could really see the personality of the people that lived in the house. Have unique types of trash, maybe make it so you come across a dead body or old love letters, have some story building outside of just the emails.

As it is currently you will have seen everything there is to see in 2-3 hours of gameplay. Base game also lacks different furbishing options. It seems like a lot of what could have made this game fun for a couple more hours is locked behind dlc. A very mediocre experience, it could be so much more.
i love it

This is a brilliant and well optimized game for those who enjoy building and decorating houses. 

Graphic:
Having a rather ill suited devices for gaming, my device has no trouble running this game at a surprisingly stable 60fps. The visuals are very well done in this game, objects and shades are well detailed and realistic.

Gameplay:
You play as a guy/gal who renovates houses for a living. To get paid, you accept jobs from your laptops, and perform various tasks of clean/pick up trash/repaint the wall/installing hardwares/placing down furnitures/destroying and rebuilding walls at your client's instructions to complete the job. While the jobs require you to follow certain instructions on how a house is renovated, you can also purchase a houses to renovated it at your own will, which you will then either turn it into your own office or initiate an auction to sell it to interested buyers, who each have their own preferences on the style/layout of the house. While the DLC are expensive by themselves, I don't find the base game lacking in contents and it has no trouble keeping me interested.

Bugs:
I have yet encounter any bugs in the base game myself, but many seem to find themselves troubled by bugs with the DLC add-ons, so I would say watch out for that. 

Conclusion:
This game offer ample amount of furnitures, wall paints and so on to let players build their dream houses themselves. While I don't believe you can build a house from ground up, the game does give you many style of houses to choose from. I think this is a great game for those who enjoys building and decorating a house.

[h3]🏠 House Flipper: The House Remodelling Adventure[/h3]

House Flipper is a game that focuses on reorganising houses from top to bottom. The game may seem ordinary at first, but once you get into it, it makes you feel like a home decoration guru. 🧹

[b]🎨 Graphics and Sounds:[/b]
The graphics and sound of the game are very satisfying. The detail of every corner of the house gives a real sense of satisfaction during the editing phase. 🖼️

[b]🕹️ Gameplay and Entertainment:[/b]
The game is generally fun and addictive. However, sometimes the missions can be a bit repetitive, a change would have been inevitable. 🎮

[b]📜 Story and Depth:[/b]
In terms of story, the game lacks the depth to keep you engrossed. There could have been a more in-depth scenario and character development, which would have made the game more attractive. 📚

[b]🌟 Game Pros[/b]
🏠 Freedom: The freedom to organise houses according to my own taste is fascinating.
🧐 Details: The details in every corner of the house make the game realistic.
[b]👎 Cons of the game[/b]
🔄 Repetitive tasks: Repetitive tasks can be boring from time to time.
📖 A Deeper Story: A more in-depth story would have increased the game's appeal.

So there are really nice bits to this game, I was hyper engaged up to the point that I started buying items. The item system is... well it's wack. Particularly the interaction of the buyers and the items. I get that is hard to make a system that objectively values a subjective thing like house design.

But for example: I was trying to build a house for a guy who wanted a really rich looking hallway and office, and the bare minimum everywhere else. I could not get that office to be considered an office, I tried everything, looking up internet guides and it just kept being a home library. And every time you do auction, you're taking this big monetary risk on this weirdly regimental system where a beautiful office you made doesn't count as an office and he's like BUT I WANTED AN OFFICE. Like is it that hard to make a room qualify as two different types of rooms at once, as long as it has all the qualifying features? And why do those qualifying features need to be so INCREDIBLY SPECIFIC. It's just lazy game design.

Also the availability of items and materials is so sorely lacking, like The Sims is way more complete and it's not even really a game specifically about building houses. And The Sims sucks, lets be frank.

Less annoying but still things to consider for the developers: the progression does not feel satisfying at all- you should slowly build from crappy materials to better and better materials, and eventually be able to finally build a beautiful state of the art home (not after only like 15 hours of play, like I could). The materials are all incredibly similarly priced, and it should be more like real life, where there's dirt cheap materials and then there's wildly impractical materials that look fantastic on the exponentially high end. And there are too many houses that are carbon copies of each other, but you knew that and were just lazy.

The demo scenes for the DLCs were not even remotely appealing. The HGTV one didn't seem to have any new content at all.

Things I liked: the buyable houses were really dirty and disgusting in the best way, and cleaning, junking, plastering, painting, and demolition all felt fantastic, you really nailed that part.

House Flipper, developed by Empyrean and published by PlayWay S.A., is a simulation game that invites players to roll up their sleeves, put on a toolbelt, and transform dilapidated houses into stunning homes. With a unique premise and a mix of simulation and renovation gameplay, House Flipper offers an enjoyable and satisfying experience for those who have a knack for home improvement.

The heart of House Flipper lies in its addictive renovation mechanics. The game allows players to tackle a variety of tasks, from cleaning up debris and repainting walls to installing new fixtures and rearranging furniture. The sense of progression is tangible as each house transforms from a neglected space into a stylish, personalized haven. The wide range of available tools and decorations provides ample creative freedom, allowing players to experiment with different styles and designs.

Graphics may not be cutting-edge, but House Flipper's visuals are clean and functional. The before-and-after transformations showcase the impact of the player's efforts effectively. The attention to detail in the objects and the overall design of the houses adds a layer of realism to the experience.

The game's economic system, where players buy, renovate, and sell properties for profit, adds a strategic element. Balancing the budget, choosing the right upgrades, and keeping an eye on market trends contribute to the simulation aspect of House Flipper, making it more than just a simple home improvement sandbox.

House Flipper's intuitive controls and straightforward gameplay mechanics make it accessible for players of all skill levels. The tutorial does an excellent job of guiding newcomers through the basics, allowing them to grasp the renovation process quickly. However, the simplicity of the game may lead to a lack of challenge for those seeking a more complex simulation experience.

While House Flipper excels in providing a satisfying renovation experience, the absence of a robust storyline or long-term goals may leave some players craving more depth. The repetitive nature of the gameplay loop, where each house follows a similar renovation pattern, could potentially lead to monotony over extended play sessions.

In conclusion, House Flipper is a fun and engaging simulation game that successfully taps into the joy of turning neglected spaces into dream homes. Its accessible mechanics, creative freedom, and the satisfaction of tangible progress make it a compelling choice for fans of home renovation and simulation games. While it may lack some of the depth found in more complex simulations, House Flipper's charm lies in its simplicity and the sheer pleasure of transforming virtual fixer-uppers into digital showcases of personal style and creativity.

Best simulator for interior design I have ever played.
I sold my soul to this game. Every time I've had a bad day at work, I launched Flippy and painted walls for hours. Wish my life was as tidy and organised as my houses in this game.

But let's take it a bit more seriously:

♥ PROS ♥
- Lots of free content, regular free updates featuring new houses and furnishing.
- DLCs priced relatively low, worth all the content you're getting.
- Adding or removing walls feature, so you can design your house to your heart's content. There will be some limitation where you can't add on more floors for example.
- Fantastic relationship with the Devs who always listen to their community and work on constant improvements on the game releasing regular patches and offering more fresh updates.

☻CONS☻
- Long loading screens.
- The game doesn't feel well optimised. Laptop users may experience loud noise when playing thee game/it may overheat as well. Desktop users shouldn't have this problem.
For people who want to renovate your own house. This game is a good choice for you.

house: flipped

If you've ever enjoyed building houses in The Sims more than actually playing the games, you'll probably enjoy this one.

You're a one-person renovation crew, starting off with performing simple cleaning jobs for clients to earn cash for their first home purchase. The jobs themselves serve as a lengthy tutorial as you start to acquire new gear (such as plastering wood wall tiles or demolishing and rebuilding walls), and the sense of general progression by acquiring perks (such as faster mounting when it comes to radiators and appliances, or using less paint when painting walls) the more you use each tool. You've got a bit more freedom when it comes to demolishing walls and rebuilding them, but you won't be impressing anyone from HGTV anytime soon.

Gameplay-wise it's boring, but a good type of boring. The mechanics themselves aren't interesting, nor is the actual story of the game--or lack thereof. The game itself gives you the ability to perform a number of remodeling actions, but the mechanics are stupidly simple. Cleaning boils down to clicking boxes and holding down the mouse button to wave your broom or mop around and watching a stain magically disappear. Painting is virtually the same, holding down the mouse button and slowly watching the paint appear on the walls one wall at a time.

After you've saved enough money from the odd jobs, you're able to buy your own home to renovate yourself. Once you've cleaned it and repaired the broken appliances (if applicable), you're able to decorate it with a variety of furnishings, décor, wallpaper, paint, carpets, and tiles. There are options for essentially every living space; kitchen, bathroom, bedroom... and strangely enough, a sauna. Once you've renovated and refurnished the house, you can put the house back on the market and sell it to a list of preset “buyers.” Each buyer has certain needs in mind (some want large bedrooms, no walls, little clutter...you get the idea!) and the game runs an auction, where the highest bidder wins. Then you use your profits to buy another house. Rinse and Repeat.

This game is overall very good. I wouldn't buy this game full-price simply because its necessary to buy the DLCs also, but at a discount, it becomes a MUST BUY. I only have the HGTV and Luxury DLCs currently, but I will likely buy the rest when on sale. They add so much to the game, and the items are worth the relief of being able to find an item that works/looks how you want it to. As House Flipper 2 comes out, I will be buying it on release. Truly, it is a great, relaxing, and fun game with creative DLCs that contribute to a well-crafted experience.

Base Game Highlights: 

Very beautiful and interesting houses (Samarta Myers lol)
Fun design possibilities
Lovely paintings/decorations
Large game
Interesting buyers
Can change staircases
Beautiful paints, interesting patterns, diverse furniture
Relaxing; mindless cleaning fun
Easy to lose time in
Many room types

Note: The HGTV DLC and the Luxury DLC are almost a REQUIREMENT and add quite a bit to the game. While the Pet, Garden, and Farm DLCs do as well, no doubt, the HGTV and Luxury DLCs add some amazing options both house and item-wise. 

Nitpicks:

Limited color options for many items.
Limited/different pattern options.
Can't expand houses.
Building rooms to fit certain furniture can be difficult, sometimes doesn't fit by like 5 cm. A bathroom I designed ended up with some spaces in between cabinets.
Doors are exclusively wooden in base game/HGTV/luxury.
Cannot put things in drawers but can in cabinets.
Small dressers/things cannot fit under beds that sit higher and should fit underneath.
Sizing is inconsistent. This is especially true in pictures; small is not small, large is not large, small is too large, large is too small, large is too large.
Buyers can be confusing to work with; some will not outbid others even when the house is perfectly to their liking.
Putting items in bookcases is unnecessarily difficult. Ladders are hard to stand on and place items on one.
Window curtains can't go through objects, some aren't short enough, some aren't wide enough, and the color/pattern options are limited in base game/HGTV/luxury.

Like I said, it is a game worth getting and enjoying, despite the nitpicks I've put in. They really are nitpicks, only mildly annoying. On the whole, I find the game relaxing and fun, so I can't stress it enough that it's worth being bought and played, even with HF2 coming out shortly.

=============

Update several hundred hours later!

With the release of the Farm DLC, we got SO MUCH new content it's insane. First, we got new animal types in addition to the Pets DLC animals. I love my little chickens so much! The ability to build entirely new buildings makes going back to older lots worth it because you can slap up a whole new house on the First Office lot, for example. 

There are a ton of jobs available with all the DLCs included, so I always have something to do. Plus the free content updates to the base game are very welcome and much appreciated. They actually did add a ton of new carpets with new textures, so that prayer was answered.

Overall, this game is solid as it could be, and I'm psyched for House Flipper 2 to come out!

"House Flipper" was love at first sight, but the flame of our passion was snuffed out as quickly as it was ignited. Ah, what sorrow! As a former Sims build mode addict, this premise of this game showed promise for scratching that itch, but I soon found myself bored with the tedium of it all. For a game based on design, there is a severe lack of base game furnishings. The developers seem to want to cash in on the contemporary era of micro-transactions, asking for even MORE of your money in exchange for content that should have always been included to begin with. I find this game disappointing at best, and insulting at worst.
I love this game. I could send hours fixing and cleaning houses (and I did).

This game is a lot of fun, makes you think about different ways to redesign houses.  Once you complete the regular game there are several things you can do to buy and renovate or redesign the houses and sell them to the AI characters. I only wish the AI characters would actually pay attention to the detail, furniture added, and not just how many bedrooms, bathrooms and if it has a kitchen or not.  I had a beautiful 3 br house made, with all expensive furniture added.  Couldn't get a decent bid on it.  Then I built a crap house with a bunch of lentils to create 5 br, 3 baths nd they gobbled it up real quick, didn't make a lick of sense to me.  Luxury DLC added a new dimension to the game, however I wish they would have added more buyers.  This problem with the buyers seem to be the only downside to this game.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead– murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded. I... I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling-out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess... I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

House Flipper is a surprisingly good game. It's a simple concept, buy houses and fix them up or change their layouts to furnish them for potential buyers, sell them for a big profit and lather, rinse, repeat. But i never felt like it got old, i start off on a property, clean it up and then my mind goes to town planning what each room should be. You can start with a very bare bones house that has unfinished walls and before long, you have a house that even you would love to live inside of. 


outside of buying and flipping houses you have a variety of odd jobs to level up to get skill points to use to use to help make things easier of yourself when working and build up your funds to start flipping. The odd jobs can be fun to do but can also help you learn what you can do with with rooms to help you with furnishing houses you buy to flip. 

It's a very chill game where you can do things at your own pace, take as long as you want or see how fast you can flip a house. theres a decent amount of stuff to do in the base game, plenty to have fun with for a good while.
Me and my mom both love this game so much and are looking forward to house flipper 2, I cant get enough of this game!

I still had a lot of fun cleaning up and decorating the different houses and played the game for a few weeks before I got bored.

This game is a great stress reliever. You get to explore the life of a house flipper, and all the responsibilities included. You can create your own dream house. You can spend hours at a time creating the best living room, or garden for yourself, or others. Great game, and would recommend!!

I am loving playing this game. You are the jack-of-all-trades. You renovate, decorate, demolish, re-model and build. It is a great game if you love interior design and decorating. There is lots of dlc, some bought and some free. It supports ultra wide screens and I have experienced no crashes in my game. There is the odd bug here or there but nothing game breaking. 

* Update after pet dlc: Still loving it and many, many more hours poured into this game!

Do yourself a favour and check out the workshop for this game too. Lots of items and great content. And do not limit yourself to houses, try out cafe's, restaurants and retail. The templates for the most part do cater to houses/apartments but with the workshop you can think outside the box. ✨

Considering how many hours I've spent on this game, YES I recommend it.
My favorite DLCs are the Luxury and Pets. I love taking a job and being told exactly what to do with minimal choices based on the customer's taste.
It'd be nice if you could sell the "houses" as things other than residences; it feels weird to sell a business to a family wanting a house.

It does have a few issues, mostly with pets; When you disable pet needs, you have to re-enable it to stop them coming with you on jobs. When you tell them not to follow you, they STILL follow you and get in the way. You can tell them to move, but it's frustrating either way. I normally just tell them to follow me to another area I've finished with and tell them to stay. Their AI needs some work, but at least they're cute... And hypoallergenic (LOL).

Can't wait to see what they do with HF2. I've played the demo more than once.

House Flipper is an absolute gem in the world of simulation games, and its impact goes beyond just virtual entertainment—it's a gateway to real-life creativity and design. This game isn't just about flipping houses; it's about unlocking your inner interior designer and turning dreams into reality, both in the digital and physical realms.

The beauty of House Flipper lies in its simplicity yet incredible attention to detail. From the moment you step into your first property, you're armed with tools and a blank canvas, ready to transform the space into something spectacular. The freedom the game offers in choosing colors, furniture, decorations, and layout is not just liberating—it's inspiring.

But here's where House Flipper transcends the screen: its real-life application. The skills and design ideas you develop while playing this game are directly transferable to your own living space. I found myself applying the concepts I learned—like efficient room layouts, color combinations, and creative use of space—to redesign my own room.

The game's ability to spark creativity and provide a risk-free environment for experimentation is truly invaluable. It encourages you to think outside the box, try new styles, and visualize how different elements can come together to create a harmonious living space.

Personally, I found that after playing House Flipper, I became more confident in making design choices for my own room. I experimented with different furniture arrangements, tried out color palettes I wouldn't have considered before, and paid more attention to the finer details that can make a room feel truly special.

Moreover, the satisfaction of seeing your virtual designs come to life in the game is akin to the joy of witnessing your real-life room transformation. It's a testament to the game's ability to inspire and empower players to explore their creativity and design potential.

In summary, House Flipper isn't just a game; it's a catalyst for unlocking your inner designer and applying newfound skills to your own living space. Its immersive gameplay, attention to detail, and ability to nurture creativity make it a valuable tool for anyone looking to explore interior design or simply wanting to breathe new life into their surroundings.

Let me start by saying, "House Flipper" has single-handedly turned me into the DIY home improvement guru I never knew I wanted to be. Move over, Chip Gaines; there's a new sheriff in town, and his name is... well, it's me, after playing this game.

From the moment I stepped into my first virtual dump, armed with a paint roller and a questionable taste in wallpaper, I knew I was in for a wild ride. Forget about real-life sweat and tears – in House Flipper, my tears were purely from laughter as I tried to paint a straight line for the umpteenth time.

The best part? I can do all the heavy lifting without actually breaking a sweat. I can demolish walls, tear down cabinets, and shatter windows with the precision of a sledgehammer-wielding ninja, all from the comfort of my ergonomic gaming chair. Who needs a gym when you can have biceps of steel from virtual demolition?

And don't even get me started on the real estate market in the game. Move over, HGTV; House Flipper is where the true drama unfolds. I've had potential buyers walk in, take one look at my neon-green bathroom tiles, and promptly leave with a disgusted emoji. It's like the game has a built-in virtual mic drop for every questionable design decision.

But fear not, fellow virtual renovators, for the joy of "undo" is always at your fingertips. Accidentally painted the entire living room neon pink? No problem! Just hit Ctrl+Z and watch your mistakes disappear faster than my hopes of ever becoming a professional interior decorator.

In conclusion, House Flipper is the game I never knew I needed – a virtual playground where I can unleash my inner Bob the Builder and create architectural masterpieces that may or may not be considered crimes against good taste. Five stars for the laughs, the tears (mostly of joy), and the satisfaction of turning pixelated dumps into virtual mansions. Move over, Ty Pennington; there's a new sheriff in town, and he's armed with a paint roller and a dream.

They have now added all of this and more. Sure I’ve had to buy a couple DLC’s along the way which isn’t ideal but what dev isn’t doing that these days? You can get them at reasonable prices from certain online retailers that may or may not be steam and they now tick all the boxes. 

The community is alive with thousands of workshop items that add whatever you desire. If there’s still not that item you wish to have then why not give modelling a go and you can add it yourself for others to enjoy?

One of the best things about House Flipper is its sheer addictiveness. It's incredibly satisfying to start with a run-down, dilapidated house and turn it into a stunning masterpiece. The variety of tasks you can tackle, from cleaning up trash and fixing broken appliances to painting walls and choosing the right furniture, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging.

The graphics are surprisingly detailed for a game of this nature. You can really appreciate the before-and-after transformations as you watch your properties go from shabby to chic. It's like a virtual HGTV show, and it's oddly therapeutic.

The game's progression system keeps you motivated as you earn money from your flips and unlock new tools and skills to enhance your abilities. There's a sense of accomplishment when you complete a project and see those virtual dollars roll in.

While House Flipper offers a lot of fun, it's not without its minor quirks. Sometimes the physics can be a bit wonky, and you might find yourself rearranging furniture or struggling to place objects exactly where you want them. However, these issues are forgivable given the overall enjoyment the game provides.

I got this out of curiosity.

I've done actual yard work, home building, restoration work, additions, remodeling, and house flipping at different times in my life, and wanted to know if a game about it could be fun.

Over 300 hours in now on one of my most played games on Steam, and yes...it's fun.  Just forgot to leave a review.

It takes out the most annoying parts of the business, and just allows you to enjoy the success.  There's no smell or body aches or unpaid invoices or trouble making ends meet.  But there is the fun of completing tasks and creativity and a zen like activity.

If you like dreaming up your own house, or just laying out some ideas, or sometimes playing around with thoughts like "what kind of apocalypse bunker / futuristic studio / ideal beach home / whatever" place you'd like to imagine...this has a lot of capabilities to let you explore that, especially with all the dlcs and user created content.

It's not perfect.  You can't do anything and everything you can imagine.  But if you do have some imagination then it's really good, and can be a relaxing place to explore some of the things you imagine.

I've played 95% of Powerwash Sim and I wanted more. This game is not it. 
The UI is painful. I got to building walls, trying to snap them into place and it's so clunky. 
Installing appliances is literally just screwing things into place, slowly. Painting is pointing your cursor at a wall and it's painted with an up and down motion.
With the tools you just make the same general back and forth motion with your hand (hurhur) and then it's done. There's not even a satisfying rustle of paper when you clean up trash. The sound effects are repetitive. 
I thought destruction would be fun but no, just as awful. The pieces kind of stick together and you have to select a specific chunk to target it, resulting in a lot of waving the pointer around to get it to trigger.
This game would benefit from a 3rd person, overhead view, similar to the Sims or other house builder games. Instead it's in first person POV and so frustrating.
I got this on sale for super cheap, so I'm not upset about the price. But I'd been hearing about this game because it's recommended highly for people who liked Powerwashing.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ (5/5)

House Flipper is a delightful and addictive simulation game that allows you to live out your inner HGTV fantasies. Whether you're an aspiring real estate tycoon or simply a fan of home improvement, this game offers a unique and satisfying experience that keeps you coming back for more.

Gameplay:
The gameplay in House Flipper is straightforward yet immensely enjoyable. You play as a one-person renovation crew tasked with buying, cleaning, decorating, and ultimately selling houses for a profit. The game offers a variety of tools and customization options, allowing you to let your creativity run wild. From mopping up dirt to installing new walls or painting rooms in your choice of colors, the possibilities are endless. The satisfaction of seeing a derelict property transform into a beautiful home is incredibly rewarding. The game's tasks are both challenging and relaxing, making it a great choice for players of all skill levels.

Graphics and Sound:
House Flipper's graphics are surprisingly detailed, and the environments are well-crafted. The game makes you feel like you're physically present in the homes you're renovating, thanks to the realistic textures and lighting. The ambient sounds, from the hum of power tools to the chirping of birds, add to the immersive experience.

Progression and Replayability:
House Flipper offers a great sense of progression. As you take on various jobs and flip houses, you earn money and experience points that can be used to unlock new tools, skills, and decorations. This keeps the gameplay fresh and motivates you to tackle increasingly complex projects. Additionally, the game's regular updates and downloadable content (DLC) provide even more ways to expand your renovation empire, ensuring that you won't run out of things to do.

Multiplayer:
While House Flipper was initially a single-player experience, the developers have introduced a multiplayer mode that allows you to collaborate with friends in renovating houses. This cooperative mode adds a new layer of enjoyment to the game, as you can work together to tackle bigger projects and create your dream homes with friends.

Conclusion:
House Flipper is a hidden gem among simulation games, offering a highly addictive and thoroughly satisfying experience for anyone who enjoys home improvement or real estate. Its simplicity, combined with its endless possibilities and the sense of accomplishment you get from turning dilapidated properties into stunning homes, make it a must-play title. The developers have continued to support the game with updates, ensuring it stays fresh and exciting. If you've ever dreamt of becoming a property mogul or just want to have some fun decorating and renovating, House Flipper is the game for you. Get ready to roll up your sleeves, grab your toolbox, and let your creativity shine in the world of house flipping!

This is a really good and relaxed game for those who doesn't like fighting and chasing some goals within a time limit. There's literally no time limit and no limit in here, maybe except the bugs. You can design and decorate different houses and spaces into something you like, which is very satisfying. Before I know it, many hours have passed. 
But this game isn't without bugs and some of the bugs are really annoying, e.g. Shuana with the big bedroom thing, sometimes buyers not recognizing spaces even if the houses have it because you stand at a wrong room, etc. The inability to do anything to sockets at the inner side of exterior walls is also driving me crazy. 
Another annoying thing is the lack of rulers and grids, so it is super hard to make sure you put all the lights, deco, and furniture symmetrically. 
Another reviewer mentioned about shady business thing. I agree with them. The base game itself is not cheap at full price, but many of others good stuff are locked behind DLCs (like the ability to tidy up the plot and mow grass) and if you buy everything at full price, your wallet gonna kaput. HIghly recommend to buy only when there's deep discounts.

House Flipper is both fun and educational and I would highly recommend it if you're into simulation gaming.

170 hours later. 

What I like: 

1> Freedom to modify a house to a degree. 

2> The Cyberpunk style lofts are fun and I enjoy them more then most of the houses 

3> I like the overall creativeness of the game.

What I dislike: 

1> Disappearing furniture as soon as you leave the room. It just kills the game. 

2> Game glitches a lot, can't finish the game. The castle crashes my game. 

3> The lights mechanic is bad. Lights turn off when you go into the next room. For the lofts this is broken. 

4> Random holes in the homes makes me fall into the stage. This happens with particular furniture and corners.


Conclusion:

This game has great potential but the developers is planning on a release of house flipper 2. They don't really care for the bugs in house flipper one. I doubt we will see any improvements on game performance but I will not be buying the second one as the first one was never really fixed to begin with. 

The add on content just breaks the game more.

Evimi kıyı köşe bir güzel temizledim. Önce perdelerimi çıkardım, koltukları içli dışlı bir güzel süpürdüm. Ardından buhar ile temizledim şöyle güzelce oh. Hazır kaldırmışken bütün koltuğun altını da süpürdüm şöyle minderleri de buharladım. Gelelim camlara şöyle bir güzel bebek şampuanıyla köpürttüm ardından çekçek yardımıyla çektim ve duruladım, iyice köşeleri köşeleri ovdum. Durulama bezine sirke koydum ve en son da sirkeyle parlattım, aynı işlemi dışlara da yaptım. Camlarda ve aynalarda bebek şampuanı kullandığım için parıl parıl parlıyor (Uzun boy'un avantajları diyebiliriz, iyice dibine kadar silebiliyorum). Halıyı temizlemeye vermek üzere kaldırdım, bütün kıyıları köşeleri süpürdüm ve yer suyuma tabi ki lavanta yağı ekledim mis gibi kokuyor. Malum büyük temizlik, şöyle havluyla bir güzel sildim. Çekilemeyen ağır şeyleri de çektim, her şeyin altını süpürdüm, tozları aldım, ardından ortalığı ve kalan yerleri sildim. En son da çekçek'in ucuna havlu taktım ve bir posta da öyle sildim. Diğer yerlerin pisliği içeri geçmesin diye havluyu kapının önüne serdim, o sırada perdelerim bitmişti elim değmişken tüm odaları perdelerini ve mecanlarını bitirdim. Ardından eve geldim, bir duş aldım ve susam ayak banyosu yaptım. Çok keyiflidi... Bütün yorgunluğum gitti.

I bought this game because it was on sale for $2.49. It ended up being a lot more fun, satisfying and engrossing than I thought. You buy houses and renovate and sell them. Pretty much exactly what it looks like. The UI itself is kinda clunky and the animations subpar compared to a AAA title, but the overall experience has been good for 25+ hours. Sometimes I like to shut my brain off and paint a house. Or lay down some tile. Or remodel a bathroom. And in this game, those things can be accomplished in as little as 3 minutes. This game isn't going to blow you away and redefine the genre. But it will keep you coming back for 20+ hours, and you'll feel pretty good about your purchase if this is something that interests you. I simply couldn't resist a game for $2.49. Thanks Steam.

Graphics and Design (4.5/5): The graphics of House Flipper are clean and well-defined. The details of objects, interiors, and structures are surprisingly realistic. The design of environments and objects is diverse, ensuring a wide range of customization options. However, in some cases, the repetitiveness of objects can lead to a sense of déjà vu.

Gameplay (4/5): The core mechanics of House Flipper focus on renovating houses, from clearing debris and dirt to choosing furniture and materials. The gaming experience is engaging and satisfying, especially for those who enjoy the creative aspect of interior design. However, some missions can become repetitive, lacking true variety in the challenges presented.

Realism and Detail (4.5/5): One of the most captivating aspects of House Flipper is its realistic approach to renovation. From repairs to decorations, every action requires attention to detail. The variety of tools and materials available adds a level of complexity that appeals to enthusiasts of realistic simulations.

Progression and Challenges (3.5/5): House Flipper's progression is based on an experience system that allows players to unlock new tools and missions as they advance. However, the lack of more complex challenges might lead to a loss of interest in the long run. The addition of more intricate objectives could provide greater motivation for continued engagement.

Social Interaction (3/5): While there are elements of social interaction, such as customer requests and house reviews, a multiplayer component is lacking, which could have further enhanced the social aspect of the game. The ability to collaborate with other players in renovating a house could have added an intriguing teamwork element.

Sound and Music (4/5): Sound effects, such as the noise of tools and the surrounding environment, are well-executed and contribute to player immersion. The soundtrack is pleasant, although at times it might become monotonous. A greater variety of music could have enriched the gaming experience.

House Flipper as I see it, has two distinct stages of game play. The first comes from when you first start the game and everything is great. I am doing missions, flipping cheap smaller houses, unlocking upgrades, and just having a good time; the "Calm Before The Storm." But then you finish the missions, 100% them perhaps, and you start switching to just flipping houses in your own style and selling them do the buyers; which is where said calm ends, and the storm begins. Because as soon as I am left to my own devices, the game play begins to really suck. I have all these options, all these homes, furniture I have never seen, and ideas I never thought about before. But I simply feel no drive to do it. As compared to the first stage where I played 15 to 20 hours over three days, playing every night for as long as my brain could handle; in the second stage I cant even bring myself to play for longer then half an hour without forcing myself to engage in bore that is continuing to do the same things over and over again without reason. Perhaps if the buyers of my homes had significantly different concept of what they want in mind from each other, then perhaps I would feel challenged to engage in different design ideas or harder to construct concepts, things that could challenge my skills and understanding. But no, every buyer is 100% happy with the same colours, same brands of furniture, and a added sauna to really boost the property value. As it is House Flipper is an okay game, I can flip houses. But the game play only lasts for as long as the story missions do before becoming dull, with nothing be done to make me truly feel like I am "House Flipper" beyond the title. Truly a perfect representation of a streamer game, play for a bit, then never play again.

I must say however, that I am extremely saddened by the state of this game, I wish it was more, I wish they truly expanded on the buyers. Because flipping houses is a fun concept, and the game does allow for quite a high degree of freedom, just fails in its delivery of that freedom to the player.
The game is super fun, but I'd definitely recommend buying the DLC's. There's so much more to do with them and it's fun! I bought them all together and recommend anyone to do that as well

House Flipper - Transforming Properties, One Brushstroke at a Time 🏡🖌️

⭐⭐⭐⭐ (4 Stars) - A delightful simulation for DIY enthusiasts

House Flipper invites players into the world of property renovation, offering a satisfying and creative experience for those who love DIY projects. While it's a commendable game, there are a few aspects to consider.

🏡 Property Renovation - Your Creative Canvas 🪛🔨
The game provides a wide range of dilapidated properties to renovate and decorate. You can unleash your inner decorator and transform these homes, one brushstroke at a time.

🧹 Cleaning and Repairs - The Satisfaction of Progress 🧽🚿
Cleaning and making repairs might seem mundane, but in House Flipper, it's oddly satisfying. The sense of progress and transformation is a key highlight.

🖌️ Creative Freedom - Design Your Dream Space 🎨🪑
The game offers creative freedom, allowing you to design rooms according to your vision. The possibilities are endless, from minimalist modern designs to cozy vintage spaces.

🛠️ Room for Improvement - Expanding the Toolbox 💡🏗️
While House Flipper is a great simulator, there's room for expansion. Adding more tools and features could further enhance the experience.

House Flipper is an enjoyable game for anyone who has ever dreamed of renovating and decorating properties. The sense of satisfaction in cleaning, repairing, and transforming spaces is a major draw. With potential enhancements, the game could become an even more exceptional simulator for DIY enthusiasts. If you have a penchant for home improvement projects and interior design, this game is a fun way to unleash your creativity. 🪛🧽🧡🖌️🚿🏡🪑🎨💡🏗️🔨

House Flipper is an incredibly satisfying game that lets you live out your renovation fantasies. From run-down properties to dream homes, you get to transform them all. The sense of accomplishment as you turn a dingy space into a beautiful living area is immensely rewarding. The wide variety of tasks and tools keeps the gameplay fresh, and there's a surprising amount of strategy involved in making the most profit. It's like an addictive puzzle, trying to figure out what will increase the property's value the most. Plus, with the addition of garden renovation, it's even more diverse. If you've ever watched a home improvement show and thought, "I can do that," House Flipper lets you prove it. The only reason it's not a perfect 5 stars is that there's always room for a little more content and customization. Still, it's a must-play for anyone with a creative spark and a love for DIY projects!
