Initially after completing the game back in 2019~ when it was just the base game and Garden DLC. I got all the achievements and thought the game was a very neat concept. Though I wish I was able to do more in the way of customization.

Fast forward to 2023 around the time when the Farm DLC releases. I realize that a lot of content, jobs, and properties were added. Some of those properties being very massive, allowing for me later to build an entire office for my “business”, a large house, and an entire garden/chicken coop area.

Anyway when I returned I was delighted to see that they added the ability to customize the pre-existing stairs in properties. But the biggest one of them all was the ability to remove the exterior doors and windows and replace them and place them wherever you’d like.

Then the Farm DLC came out and added the ability to build additional houses on a lot, which made me ecstatic. Although you can’t do much in the way with the preexisting houses on an occupied lot. You can't add floors or change it per say, but you can add additions onto it though. But they added empty plots to truly unleash this game's potential.

Overall this game is relaxing, and has plenty of content, the base game alone has a fair amount, and you can add loads more via buying the DLCc which are worth it as they drastically expand on the game’s systems.

But if you’re not content with what the game has to offer in terms of furniture and what not, the game has the steam workshop which has loads of useful tools and really nice looking furniture.

As I just “finished” or “100%” the game as of writing, I highly recommend this game to everyone who may be interested. Here's to hoping House Flipper 2 turns out to be a successful successor.

Title: Turning Dilapidation into Dream Homes: House Flipper

Review:

House Flipper, developed by Empyrean and published by PlayWay S.A., is a refreshing and addictive take on the simulation genre. As the ultimate one-person renovation crew, this game hands you the keys to rundown properties, challenges you to transform them into luxurious spaces, and, in the process, turns your interior design fantasies into reality. With its satisfying gameplay loop, creative freedom, and attention to detail, House Flipper is an absolute delight for aspiring decorators and virtual renovators.

At the heart of House Flipper lies the joy of transformation. Starting with derelict houses, garages, and other properties, the game tasks you with cleaning, repairing, and redecorating to boost their value. The sense of satisfaction that comes from turning a grime-covered, dilapidated room into a stylish living space is immensely rewarding. The game's intuitive controls and user-friendly interface ensure that even newcomers to simulation games can dive in and start flipping houses with ease.

One of the game's standout features is the extensive variety of tasks and customization options available. From painting walls and laying flooring to installing appliances and arranging furniture, every aspect of the renovation process is at your fingertips. The extensive catalog of furniture and decor items offers endless possibilities, allowing you to create spaces that range from cozy rustic cottages to sleek modern apartments. The freedom to experiment with different styles and designs ensures that each renovation project is a unique and personal endeavor.

The game's career mode provides structure and guidance while allowing for creative expression. Completing renovation jobs for virtual clients not only earns you in-game currency but also unlocks new tools, skills, and customization options. The progression system ensures a sense of accomplishment as you gradually expand your renovation empire and tackle increasingly complex projects.

House Flipper excels in attention to detail. Every object, from tiny decorations to large appliances, is meticulously rendered, and the game's graphics capture the essence of different architectural styles. The environments are vibrant and immersive, with realistic lighting and textures that add depth to your creations. The sound design complements the visuals, with satisfying audio cues accompanying every action, from hammering nails to vacuuming carpets.

Moreover, the game benefits from its modding community. Players can access a wealth of user-created content, including new furniture items, house models, and additional renovation tools. This active modding scene extends the game's longevity and ensures that there's always something fresh to discover and incorporate into your projects.

In summary, House Flipper is a delightful blend of creativity, relaxation, and entrepreneurship. Its addictive gameplay, coupled with the freedom to design and renovate to your heart's content, offers a satisfying and immersive experience. Whether you're an interior design enthusiast, a simulation game lover, or simply someone who enjoys the art of transformation, House Flipper welcomes you into a world where dilapidation meets dream homes, making it an enjoyable and engaging simulation title.

UPDATED REVIEW 14/10/2023:

After having put several hours into House Flipper and owning every DLC...

House Flipper is for sure my all time favourite renovating simulation game. You can do so much in this game, it's actually insane and it never get's boring . You start out with a terrible house, you have a laptop where you can do jobs from random NPC's through emails wanting you to do things for them. TIP: Do every job till you receive no more emails then move on to the bigger jobs 'map of jobs', then spend your earned money on whatever you have your eyes on. You have total freedom in House Flipper, the design is at your finger tips, you can do anything you like. Just be aware, there are haunted houses, so it's not entirely a realistic renovating game, it's more of a thriller in some houses that feels like someone is watching you all the time, hehehehehe...okay...let's be honest here...I am very jumpy in real life, I get scared very easily so anything will give me a fright.

I recommend buying all the DLC's first before trying out the game, it's worth the full House Flipper experience, trust me, if you love renovating, you'll love this game then. You can even put the bits and pieces together such as air conditioners etc. You can mow the lawn, have a pool, have pets, etc. Great game, see if you enjoy it.

Oh, and House Flipper 2 releases on the 15th of December 2023. :-)

5/5

Game Rating: PG (Mild Violence, some things in House Flipper will scare younger players, even adults).

Genre: Indie, Simulation

RELEASE DATE: 17 May, 2018

Ah, House Flipper, the game where you can unleash your inner Bob the Builder without the hassle of permits and the fear of persistent pants stains! It's like a dream come true for all you DIY enthusiasts out there, and let me tell you, it's a rollercoaster ride through the world of virtual home improvement.

Now, imagine this: you're tearing down walls, installing appliances like a pro, and painting walls with the finesse of an artist. All of this, and not a single stain on your pants! I mean, who needs a contractor's license or those pesky city permits when you've got House Flipper?

But here's the kicker - you'll get so engrossed in this game that you'll start questioning your life choices. Why are you fixing virtual toilet pipes when there's a real-life leaking disaster waiting for your attention? Priorities, my friend, priorities!

Now, let's talk about those glitches. Yes, there are a few hiccups in the game that can sometimes block your path to virtual renovation stardom. But who cares when you're watching your dream house on your PC screen shining like a beacon of perfection? Meanwhile, your real house might just crumble to the ground, but hey, at least you're a virtual home improvement guru!

In the end, House Flipper is a fun and addictive game that lets you live out your wildest DIY fantasies. Just remember, when you're knee-deep in virtual house paint and tile, don't forget about that leaking toilet in the real world. Your pants may stay clean, but your real-life house might not be as forgiving!

This game has a bunch of things going for it and a good vibe overall, but lacks a few things that would make me want to play it more. First it lacks a sense of progression, I feel like after 2 hours playing the game I saw everything there is to do in it and everything from now on will be a bit repetitive. The tools and everything you do feels underwhelming and unsatisfying. The game lacks a timelapse of before/after photos when you finish a mission, it lacks a good UI.

I will go back to it every once in a while, this isn't a bad game, but I feel like 93% positive reviews is too high for a game that is far from perfect. At time of reviewing it's at -90% though so definitely worth a try at this pricetag, you might enjoy it more than I did.

Even though I do like this game and will continue to play it, I seriously can't recommend it.

After 5 years, they're abandoning this game for "House Flipper 2", They're also abandoning it without fixing any of the bugs, and most likely won't patch anything when House Flipper 2 releases.

I'm guessing they're abandoning this game due to the recent issues with Unity, but that's not an excuse when I'm still encountering bugs just in the base game, and according to others, the Farm DLC has been broken/full of bugs since its release in April.

I'm still hoping they'll continue to work on this game (even if it's just a few patches), but until I know for sure, my review will stay negative.

Also, the majority of the DLCS (specifically the garden DLC) should've been base game; instead, they went for the EA route, making them a DLC.

This game changed my outlook on cleaning. Initially, I was skeptical, thinking, "I don't clean in real life, why would I want to do it in a game?" But once I tried it, I found it to be incredibly therapeutic. After buying the game, I decided to tackle my room in a methodical way, just like I did in the game. I broke the cleaning process down into smaller tasks and approached it step by step. As a result, my bed is made, and my closet has some space now. It's amazing how the feeling of achievement in the game translated into the real world. 10/10 for this unexpected benefit!

Before releasing a second version of the game, perhaps fixing some of the glaring issues with the first game should have been precedent. It's next to impossible to place pools, decking or paving slabs and get anything to line up properly, without a lot of trial and error! A snap tool might have helped with that. Come on designers, get real already. Considering the genre of the game, a simple way to line up furniture, fixtures and surfaces should have been a priority. This really should have been addressed before releasing the sequel to the game. But it looks like all Play Way and their developers care about are DLC money grabs. Unless these issues are addressed for the first game I'll never buy another Play Way production again. Stop being cheap and start releasing base games with more content included. I got this game in safe thinking “hm I guess this could be fun” and have put 160 hours into it!!! I absolutely love this game - as an ex-set designer turned photographer, this game is so cozy and creative! Especially with the DLC packs. I got all of them in a sale bundle for around $25 and it’s totally worth it for the variety it adds to the design options (if you’re crazy like me - I be looking at room inspo on Pinterest to create spaces) 

HOWEVER!! There is one I’m hoping for in House Flipper 2: 

- Client Feedback!m/Rating/Review System! As a freelancer, the emails were hilarious to me. I hope you bring them back because that was such a fun aspect of the game! And so true to my life; my first negotiation was for $1 and the response was “not a chance.” It really felt like how clients be sometimes 😂 With that, I don’t feel the amount of money you make depends on how well you do, at all. As long as you check all the boxes, u get the money. I’m not sure if it’s possible but it would be rad to have some sort of ‘grading’ metric. 

Otherwise I’m SUPER excited for HF2 and if you are considering any early creator releases I would love to be considered 🙏 it also looks like it may be compatible with VR which I am excited to try if it is.

"House Flipper" is a unique video game that offers a relaxing and immersive home renovation experience, though it can be a bit tedious at times. I have more hours on the xbox ;)

However, the gameplay can sometimes become repetitive and even tedious, especially during the initial stages of a project when you're tasked with cleaning, scrubbing, and painting every nook and cranny of a house. While realism is a strong point, it can also feel like a grind. The game's mechanics could benefit from a bit more streamlining to maintain the relaxing atmosphere while reducing monotony.

Where "House Flipper" truly shines is through its DLCs. The Luxury DLC and Pets DLC add fresh and enjoyable elements to the game. The Luxury DLC lets you work on high-end properties with extravagant designs, adding a touch of elegance to your flipping endeavours. The Pets DLC, on the other hand, introduces adorable animals into the game, bringing more life and warmth to the homes you work on. These DLCs provide a breath of fresh air and enhance the overall experience significantly.

n conclusion, "House Flipper" is a relaxing and immersive game that offers a unique experience in the world of home renovation.

Looking forward to the House flipper 2.

Edit - October 2023.

I can't believe it's been 5 years since i've reviewed this game. This game has come such a long way in 5 years. I've spent hours and hours, doing the missions, cleaning and redecorating housings and most recently doing farm stuff and building houses. The detail were allowed to go into building, painting, decorating, windows, doors etc etc is incredible. This is one of my favorite games of all time, probably top 3. I'll pop in the game every once in a while and there's always new stuff and over the last month, i've gotten absolutely hooked again. Also after rereading my original review, the Devs implemented everything i wanted plus tons more. Once again, thanks Devs!


I love this game.  I used to spend hours playing The Sims just decorating the house, well this is 100x better. I love every aspect of it. The painting, assembling appliances, furnishing and even the sweeping and cleaning up trash. I've beat the "missions" part of it and i've still been playing this game for hours. There's just so much to do. I make bizzare houses, super expensive houses, houses i would like to live in, and right now i turning a house into a maze using the large blocks. (Would love an option to auto keep buying the same item.) (There may be one but i haven't found it.) I'm looking forward to new houses, missions, maybe even a plot of land so i can build a house from scratch. There's really so much potential with this game. 
Thanks Devs!

I absolutely love this game. Just the base game itself is addicting. If you buy any of the DLCs, it only adds to the fun and excitement of playing. More choices, more items to explore, more properties to unlock, more tools to use. You play at your own pace. You can either cater to the in-game buyers or you can just go all out and do what you want the way you want.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys designing and/or being creative. I have actually used elements of this game to help me make choices in my own real-world house. And if you purchase the farm DLC, you can build your own house from the ground up, choosing either to build your own design or try to replicate houses from movies or TV shows. I've done both and it's very fun and entertaining.

Took a break from work only to indulge myself into manual labor. 

10/10

Building a house I can’t afford.

Can't wait for more.

While this is the first PC game I've really put a ton of time into, I've played countless games on other platforms like xbox, playstation, various nintendo devices, etc. ranging from call of duty, to skyrim, to the sims franchise and tons of mario games but I've never found one like this. 

 I've played this game on steam for nearly 500 hours at the time of writing this, and at least another few hundred hours on the switch. I've also played it with no DLC's and with all of them available and recommend it either way (though the extra content truly expands the game and makes it so much more enjoyable). You can design the same home in so many different ways and I think I fell in love with the game so much because of the creativity as well as how relaxing it is to play. 

I was a little nervous transitioning to playing on my Macbook considering I had previously fried my old one by playing sims 4 on it, however it's done surprisingly well with some adjustments to the settings here and there. Other than random small tweaks, there's not a single complaint I have about it! With recent patches, all of the DLC's work fine together, granted some do lag a little more than others, and being able to add custom content from the workshop has been exceptionally enjoyable. 

I can't recommend this game enough to others. I've been able to create spaces I'm proud of and consider myself apart of the community by participating in online groups. There's so much to discover and I've learned a ton just by seeing work from other players!

The game keeps getting better and better each time I play.  I love this game.  I would like to be able to add rooms to existing houses without dividing a room in half.  I mean I'd love to be able to expand on a very small house and make it a mansion.  It's possible they have added that feature already and I haven't experienced it yet.  Still playing!

This game is a very calming and zen experience if you can manage to ignore the angry mob yelling at you because they don't like your artistry. 

 If you enjoyed ACNH's Happy Home Academy DLC(and just decorating Animal Crossing houses in general), you will LOVE this. I loved getting to unleash my inner interior designer demon. 

 I can imagine the fixing and cleaning aspect of the game would be similar to powerwash simulator. It was definitely a "turn your brain off" type activity for me, and I loved every second of it. 

 The game could use more content, though. I hear it's a bit empty without the DLCs(especially farm and pets dlc) and I definitely agree. I guess that's what DLCs are for, but I'm not cashing out 16,500 won for every dang DLC. Guess I'll have to wait for a sale. 

7/10 :)

Incredible simulator game, capable of sucking you in for hours at a time. The HGTV DLC is worth it from the start, mostly for the before and after shots of your homes when you sell them or finish the job. I am very excited for the sequel to come! This game appeases the tidier in you, the creative, the constructive, and the imaginative.

Update: As you can see I put in quite a bit more time from the first time I reviewed this game. It is crazy how much has been added with the pets DLC and farm DLC. They have done such a good job with this game when it comes to simulators. It would be cool if there was a little more focus (just a little) on the business side of being a home flipper. It would be nice to have need for money a bit more, because really just playing the game you get money and it just sits there mostly. I am not sure how this will be done, however I think it could add more to the immersion. 

P.S. I played the demo for the next one and I hope they still add more to this one, because I was not impressed. It added a lot more tediousness with cleanup and reminds me of the not very good simulators on steam, where it is too much and nit picky rather than how clean and smooth this game is.

I got this game a couple weeks ago and have been playing it nonstop.  If you're like me and spend hours decorating your house and choosing your outfits in games like the Sims or Animal Crossing, then House Flipper is perfect for you.  I generally gravitate toward "cozy," laid-back games that allow me to progress and explore at my own pace, and this is definitely one of them.

House Flipper offers dozens of quests that feature many aspects of home renovation, such as decorating, budgeting, and demolition, and the game does a great job of guiding new players as you unlock more building modes.  The more quests you complete, the more skill points you acquire, which makes flipping your houses much easier.

In addition to completing quests, you can also buy homes to renovate on your own.  You can keep any house that you buy for yourself, or you can sell it to a buyer - if the house meets their specifications, you'll get a large profit for your hard work!  Most buyer preferences are broad and allow for a lot of artistic freedom, giving you the opportunity to customize your homes exactly the way you want.

One of the best aspects of the game is the relaxed pace.  There are no time restrictions or penalties, so whether you feel like completing quests or flipping houses to sell, you'll never feel like you're missing out on anything.  You can take your time decorating and renovating to your heart's content and earn money at your own pace.

As much as I enjoy House Flipper, I do wish there were more quests available.  After binge-playing the game for a few weeks, I finished every quest and even flew through the HGTV DLC.  Additionally, I would've liked it if lawn mowing and gardening were available features on the base game instead of being a separate DLC.  That said, I think the game is wonderful overall and most definitely deserves a spot in your "cozy game" rotation.
it's really fun and satisfying. It is also super calm and relaxing

Edit: I am updating this review. My first review was in 2018. It is now 2023 and I own everything there is to House Flipper, I own it on console and my switch. When HF first launched a few years back I won't lie, there was a lot missing. There was a lot I had put that I wished there was in the game. 2023 has come and now we can have a farm and animals. I am anxiously waiting HF2 because I am so addicted to this game. About a year ago, if that, there was issues with the cloud saves and I ended up losing my game, had finished it completely, but I have had to start halfway over with it and honestly, I ain't even mad about it. This is truly one of my all time favorite games to just sit for hours and renovate houses. I have built my childhood home, dream homes, and everything in between. 10 out of 10 would HIGHLY recommend this game!

Definitely highly recommend, although suggest you buy it on sale, or at least the DLCs, since they're genuinely the best part of this game. I feel that the base game is honestly a little lacking in a lot of aspects, but with the expansions this is genuinely one of my favorites, and I will likely be playing it for decades to come, and will of course also be getting the next generation. I will however still be playing this version as I really do love it as is. Personally i got the game on sale, with every DLC for the same price as the game normally costs alone, and am obviously biased in the sense that i basically got most of the game for free. But even with that in mind, I'd still recommend the game to anyone interested in house design, architecture, interior design, pets (pets dlc), farming (farm dlc), garden-scaping (garden dlc), wannabe millionaires (luxury dlc), and of course those who wish they could host their own renovation tv-show (hgtv dlc), and of course those who just enjoy fucking up the lives of the people around them by completely trashing the houses you work on, and selling the dumbest looking houses you can come up with. Its honestly a lot of fun, and there's so many ways you can play this game, sort of like the sims. So yeah, definitely recommend if you like games similar to the sims, but a bit more building oriented, and slightly more realistic.

Not everyone will get enjoyment from a simulation of cleaning or remodeling homes, and doing yard work. But it is a nice relaxing change of pace from other games and it lets you get creative with the jobs you take on. You can easily play this game on casual and get lost in what you're doing for hours. For people who like to organize, get satisfaction for cleaning and remodeling while getting to express their creativity this game is probably for you.

House Flipper is a relaxing game about cleaning, designing, and decoration various living spaces. The missions are straightforward and to the point, meaning it tells you what items to buy and what colors to paint, causing them to sometimes feel tedious. However this game outside of those missions, where you get to pick the location and design according to your heart's desires excels in allowing that to happen. 
The DLCs are also a decent addition, adding in a gardening/landscaping option and more design choices for the player. But once again, the missions in them continue to be a bit tedious. Overall though, I can recommend this game as a good relaxing game.

Right from the beginning of the game, I invested time and effort into creating beautiful rooms to impress potential buyers and provide excellent services. However, it became clear that beauty doesn't matter in this game, not because it's subjective, but because the characters don't take it into account. This made House Flipper feel like a boring job of just moving furniture and cleaning, without any depth or meaning.

Selling Houses:
When it's time to sell a house, the process is disappointingly simplistic. The house goes up for auction, and if it meets a character's predetermined criteria, they place the highest bid and acquire the property. This predictability removes any sense of challenge or excitement from the selling aspect of the game.

Lack of Lasting Impact:
One of the most disheartening aspects of House Flipper is the lack of lasting impact. Even if you put in considerable effort to create a masterpiece worthy of an architectural magazine, there is no trace of it after the sale. The game only provides a sales history with photos of the house in its initial condition. It would greatly enhance the experience if players had the ability to customize the listing photos, similar to a real estate listing.

Overall Disappointment:
Regrettably, my experience with House Flipper left much to be desired. The game lacks depth and fails to provide a sense of accomplishment or fulfillment. It falls short in several areas, making it difficult for me to consider it a complete and satisfying game. Moreover, considering its shortcomings, the price of the game feels unjustified.

Overall, my experience with House Flipper was disappointing. It lacks depth and a sense of accomplishment, falling short in several areas. Considering its flaws, I can't recommend it as a worthwhile purchase.

I would've put a positive review but this game has a BIG issue. The gameplay. First of all i recommend getting it on sale it's not worth £20. Secondly, this game can get very very boring within the first 10 hours. You practically unlock every tool and almost  get everything fully upgraded and gets boring painting walls and decorating huge houses like the Family home or the Castle. They seem like late game houses but the truth is you can get everything unlocked and beat the game if you play for a straight 2 days. It just doesn't seem worth the price and gets quite boring. It doesn't have much variety and you sell to the same people with the same preferences. You can't even get a refund after 2 hours because of their refund policy. Save your money for House Flipper 2 I'm hoping it's better and maybe implements Ai to make whoever you sell the house random or maybe make different randomised houses. Many other people have the same complaint where the game gets to bland and boring so don't think I'm the only who mad about this. Wait for sale or don't waste your money on this and wait for the second one.

You start out with a dump of a place.  Go out and take jobs, some more challenging than others.  Fulfill contracts, make money, get bigger jobs and bigger challenges.  Some jobs are more creative, some more rigid.  You can demo, build, redecorate, decorate.  Buy, sell for a profit, search out other properties and get bigger and better.
House Flipper presents an innovative idea - what if you combined a dad game and an autism game? This is what you get, and my God is it glorious.

This has become one of my go-to games. It's a great building sim that isn't too challenging. It's got enough diversity and has added enough features over time that anyone who has a creative bone and a little patience can create a masterpiece of a home. There are challenges in the form of renovating clients homes while the real money comes from renovating the dilapidated homes that are for sale. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys casual games, reno-sims, or those who are very detail oriented. Because the details you add to these homes absolutely do matter.

Strong 9, Light 8

"Why would I wanna play a game where all I'm doing is chores? Isn't that what games are supposed to help us avoid doing?" - Some Guy. Not all the time Johnny, it can be relaxing depending on the execution.

[h1]Positives[/h1]

+ Good atmosphere.
+ Great replay value.
+ Steam Workshop support.
+ Large variety of items to buy.
+ Good aesthetics and graphics.
+ You can customize your own home to your hearts content.
+ It takes the concept of chores and makes it relaxing and somewhat fun.

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- The game is kinda short without DLCs.

It is really fun but I have a few gripes of my own, I am kind of a dork about simulators so don't take my opinions as your own.

Not everything is interactive.  It's frustrating.  Sometimes you can open cabinets, sometimes you cannot.  
You cannot place things into drawers, why?  
Sinks do not work.  
You don't need to hook up ovens, stoves or sinks in the kitchens.  
Walking through grass sounds like walking on plastic.  Doors opening uses the AOL 'online' notification sound.  
Not all TVs work
Computers do not work (I'm talking about turning on, showing a desktop, not actually functioning as a real computer)

Again, I am a simulation freak so I will up-vote this as obviously it is very fun.  But I wanted to say my own issues with the game, that I do not think would ever really be addressed as they are almost like asking to make Sims a first person game.  Which is my actual fantasy.  But I think it s stupid to actually expect those types of things so yes, it is very fun and is very involved and the DLCs are extremely neat.

House flipper is a nice  simulator, I personally bought it because I was interested in the garden dlc but I ended up buying all the dlc's. Same issue with the hammer when you want to destroy a wall or use the mop when you need to clean the floor. People said to switch between equipment but it works 1 out of 3  times. It's frustrating. 
Over time I played around 100 hours so imagine having to exit the game and come back everytime. I hope the same issue won't be in House flipper 2. It will take you around 100 hours to get 100% if you are after the achievements, probably less if you rush but I took my time. If you can, try and buy it when it’s on discount, I got everything for £30. For the amount of content it's worth it. See you in House Flipper 2!

I hesitantly recommend this game, and only if you can find it for 70% off, like I did.

Pros: Was able to get about 7 hours of enjoyment out of it, so the  1 hr = $1 rule. applies. It does have a zen "ah, I'm cleaning up messy houses" element for a brief while.

Cons: Gets redundant pretty quickly. Some bugs exist--like the inability to paint over or wash off the graffiti on or even replace the "Walter White" garage door. Buying stuff could be far better categorized, and saving searches improved. It's really hard to find just "white" paint by merely searching or scrolling through the paints.  Very annoying. Also, why is it that a room doesn't count as a bedroom when you flip it unless you buy a bed to put in it? Who buys a house that already has beds and furniture??? You get the idea pretty quickly that stuff like garish colors on walls and ridiculously transparent doors for rooms don't seem to matter to potential buyers. 

Essentially, it could have been thought through with much more accuracy and depth.

A relative recommended this game to me and I didn't think it would be my thing but it's surprisingly addictive!

Basically you build skills by doing a bunch of jobs for clients and then use the money you make to purchase a house and then flip it for a profit.  The various potential buyers all have different needs, so the key to making the most profit is to cater to the top bidder.  That's the game in a nutshell.  

The REAL game, however, is spending hours and hours playing around with the design tools to make the perfect house.  The PC version is especially good because you can upload any photo you want to make it a painting.  A lot of people have found creative ways to use this feature such as making photos look like windows outside or covering up entire walls with them.  There are many, many possibilities for design in this game.   

While this game is great, I do have a few complaints.  Placement can be finicky at times.  For example, doors have to be placed correctly the first time because you can't move them.  Also, the tile/panel spreading tool tends to stretch out beyond the boundaries of the room so it can sometimes mess up the walls of an adjacent room.  Lastly, the garbage you have to pick up can sometimes spawn in an area outside the map which can make it difficult to locate for 100% completion, though during my latest playthrough I didn't have this problem so they may have fixed this.  

Anyway, I highly recommend this game if you're into design and want something relaxing to play.  The job and business components are more of an afterthought because of how easy they are but I still had fun with them.
This is my favorite game to relax with and I can't wait to see what the sequel brings!

Addictive gameplay with a variety of different tasks.  If you want to work on a bigger project, you flip houses.  If you want something smaller and faster, you do jobs.  All the DLCs also have very different vibes, each with unique tools and tasks, which can make the game feel fresh even after hours and hours of play.

A bit buggy at times and missing a few quality-of-life features, but ultimately very charming.  Absolutely would recommend not just the game but all of the DLCs, and the recent addition of the DLC demo is a great way to explore whether you want just the base game or the whole package.  Steam workshop custom items also boost the already-high replay value.

Wasn't originally planning on getting the sequel, as I almost never buy Steam games until they're on sale, but my love for this game has me genuinely considering buying the sequel on release.  Would still recommend this one though because the current price can't be beat.

Renovation Mastery Unleashed: Diving into the World of House Flipper

Rating: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

House Flipper takes the satisfying concept of turning dilapidated spaces into stunning abodes and transforms it into an addictive virtual experience. As a fan of both simulation and renovation games, I was excited to dive into this unique title that combines creativity, design, and business strategy.

The core gameplay of House Flipper revolves around purchasing neglected properties, cleaning, renovating, decorating, and ultimately selling them for a profit. The game offers a wide range of options for each step of the process, from tearing down walls to selecting paint colors and furnishings. This flexibility encourages players to unleash their inner interior designer and experiment with various styles, layouts, and combinations.

Visually, House Flipper is surprisingly detailed. The transformation of rundown rooms into stylish living spaces is incredibly satisfying to witness. The variety of furniture, decorations, and equipment available allows for a high degree of customization, ensuring that each project feels unique. While the graphics may not be on par with some AAA titles, they do their job well and provide a clear representation of the changes you're making.

One of the standout features of House Flipper is its sense of progression. As you complete more projects and accumulate wealth, you can invest in skills and tools that enhance your abilities. This progression system adds a layer of depth to the game and keeps you motivated to take on bigger challenges.

However, House Flipper isn't without its minor flaws. Some of the controls and mechanics can be a bit clunky, especially when placing objects or fine-tuning details. Additionally, while the game's core loop is engaging, it can become slightly repetitive after numerous flips. More varied objectives or additional gameplay elements could help alleviate this repetition.

The game also lacks a true sense of story or personal connection with the properties you're flipping. Adding more narrative elements, such as dealing with unique sellers, exploring the histories of the houses, or having ongoing interactions with clients, could enhance the overall immersion.

Despite these shortcomings, House Flipper is undeniably addictive. The feeling of accomplishment that comes from transforming a rundown wreck into a stylish haven is truly satisfying. It's a game that offers a creative outlet while appealing to the inner entrepreneur in all of us.

In conclusion, House Flipper is a must-play for fans of simulation, design, and renovation games. It successfully captures the thrill of turning neglected spaces into something beautiful and profitable. While it may not be flawless, its unique premise, customization options, and sense of progression make it a worthy addition to any gamer's library. Whether you're a budding designer or a business-savvy player, House Flipper offers a satisfying and enjoyable experience that will keep you flipping properties for hours on end.

I used to love this game, but months after the Farm DLC release, I'm still having the same issue with the livestock gates. Initially when they're installed, they'll work fine, but if I leave to another house, I come back and find I literally can't get through these gates anymore. I've just stopped playing all together, because I was really looking for to the livestock part of the farm DLC, and it's just been a disappointment. I jump on every few weeks to see if it's been fixed, but haven't fully played since the farm DLC release, and probably won't be until that bug is finally gone.

If that isn't something that would bother you, I'd actually still recommend the game, especially with some of the new features, such as extra stair options and the ability of making a balcony. There's such a huge range of items and customisation available, and the pets DLC is actually pretty awesome.

Update: 25.08.2023 - I no longer recommend this game. With the recent update, I loaded up the game to see if the fence gate issue might have been fixed. Not only is that bug still  not fixed, but my save data is a mess. I've lost so much progress and time consuming creative designs, that it's just not worth investing any time in this game any more. This isn't the first time I've lost save data, it's not even the second or third time. I've had enough of being let down by the folks behind this game. House flipper used to be one of my few de-stressors, and now it's not even playable when my save data is just going to vanish

Same old problem - Steam won't let me leave a neutral review. This isn't a bad game by any means but there is one particularly annoying aspect to it. Most of the time when you try to place something in an area where you have to place it the game will say "there isn't room" when clearly there is. This happens a lot. It's not game breaking just maddeningly annoying and has caused me to quit the game out of sheer frustration on many occasions because you can't finish what you are doing. You are trying to finish a job and the game just will not let you - as an example you will be given a section where you have to lay turf but when you try to lay it you are told there isn't room even though there clearly is. Another point I can't understand is why you have to stop laying turf when you come to a plant or a tree but when mowing the lawn you can go right through such obstacles. These might seem like minor gripes but when it keeps on happening it gets frustrating. That aside the game is good and can be fun if they'd only be a bit more flexible with their boundaries to prevent the problems I have mentioned (to be honest it seems to mainly occur on the garden flipper jobs). All in all you can get a lot of hours of fun from this game just watch out for the "there isn't room" annoyance.
Something else that has really irked me is that they have released a new farm dlc but have changed the minimum specs for running it. The game runs on 8 GB RAM but they've upped the minimum specs to 12 GB RAM for the dlc so as I only have 8 GB RAM I can't play this dlc - still the reviews for this dlc are "mixed" so I'm probably not missing anything.

I'm mixed on this game. You get what you pay for. You do flip houses. I just wish it was a little less soulless. A lot of times where I wanted to interact with something I had just built, the option to do so just simply isn't there. You can build all the TVs, couches, sinks, and showers you want and it may look pretty, but at the end of the day they're just props and that's what bugs me. When you think you can interact with something, you can't and it gets demotivating. "Why build this shower?" "Why build a TV?" if they're all props. And a couple mechanics just don't make sense. I'll start with the office which is just one big prop (take a shot everytime I say prop). You can have the entire thing be empty with just a computer and there's nothing stopping you from doing so. You can complete the entire game just ignoring your home base and focusing on flipping homes which at that point, what is the point? The sleep mechanic is, and I cannot stress this enough, actually useless. Hey devs, wanna know an idea that I thought of in less than 5 seconds? Make your character fatigued if you ignore sleep for long enough and as result you work slower. I know, crazy. I understand how criticizing a game without an offered solution is pointless so I'll try to offer some of my suggestions. As I said, let us interact with the world more. If I build a couch, I wanna be able to sit on it. If I build a gaming pc, why can't I play a flappy bird mini game? I know there's cars but I haven't got to them just yet but if I had to guess, they're un-customizable just using context clues. And I haven't even gotten to the flipping part yet in this review. In short, it's just repetitive after a while and it really didn't feel intuitive.  Some mechanics are horribly unbalanced. Some jobs will have you pick up ungodly amounts of trash which is just straight up not fun. Simple as. It got so bad to the point where I had to use an auto-clicker. Anything that needs to be refilled in your hands, god help me, is just atrocious. Wallpaper is by far the biggest offender. I had to have broken my wrist with the amount of times I had to look back at the floor to left click and get a new batch of wallpaper and there's no small batch, medium batch, and large batch like there is paint. So, you go to buy more, right..? WRONG. The devs had to fuck up that mechanic too. If you are holding literally anything inside your hands, you can't buy more of something. You have to put it down then you can buy something from the shop. If both your hands are occupied, you can't even open the menu that brings you to the shop. For what it's worth, I did have fun playing this game and if you like to build your own spaces, get it but if you want anything beyond mindless left clicking and a list of tasks, look somewhere else please. Side rant: I really hope HF2 has a story but if it doesn't, it is what it is. A good example would be teardown. Horrible game but you start from the bottom and you complete more and more daunting tasks as you make a name for yourself. This game does have progression but it's in the background. So you don't really know that you're making a name for yourself, the game kind of just throws tougher jobs at you without any real reason behind it.

Maybe I just like interior design but I've had this game for years now and have always loved it. I have all the dlcs for the game. It definitely has improved over the years. I would recommend it, though sometimes I get the creeps playing it as if someone's watching me.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

"House Flipper" offers a unique and addictive gameplay experience that lets you step into the shoes of a renovator and designer extraordinaire. Developed by Empyrean and published by PlayWay, this simulation game lets you transform dilapidated properties into stunning homes, channeling your creativity and strategic thinking.

Gameplay:
The heart of "House Flipper" lies in its engaging gameplay mechanics. You're tasked with purchasing rundown properties, cleaning them up, renovating, decorating, and finally selling them for a profit. Each property presents different challenges and possibilities, requiring you to manage resources wisely, prioritize tasks, and cater to the specific needs of potential buyers.

Renovation and Design:
The game offers a surprisingly extensive range of tools and items for your renovations, from painting walls and laying tiles to installing furniture and fixtures. The customization options are impressive, allowing you to experiment with various design styles and create spaces that reflect your personal taste.

Progression:
As you successfully renovate and sell properties, you'll earn money and experience points. Experience unlocks new tools, skills, and options, giving you a sense of growth and achievement as you progress through the game. This feeling of advancement adds a layer of satisfaction to the gameplay.

Realism and Immersion:
"House Flipper" excels in its attention to detail. From the way you meticulously clean stains and dirt to the accurate portrayal of construction and interior design tasks, the game captures the essence of the real-world renovation process. This realism contributes to a satisfying sense of accomplishment when you witness the transformation of a once-neglected property.

Challenges:
While the gameplay loop is addictive, some players might find it repetitive over extended periods. The process of cleaning, renovating, and decorating can become somewhat formulaic, especially as you encounter similar tasks in different properties.

Graphics and Performance:
The graphics are serviceable but not groundbreaking. The game's visual style is simple and functional, focusing more on the details of the properties themselves rather than eye-catching aesthetics. Performance can vary, especially when dealing with larger properties and complex designs.

Community and Updates:
The game has a dedicated community that shares their creative designs and tips. The developers have continued to support the game with updates, adding new properties, tools, and features to keep the experience fresh and engaging.

Conclusion:
"House Flipper" offers an enjoyable and immersive experience for those who have a penchant for design and renovation. Its unique gameplay loop, along with a satisfying sense of progression, makes it an ideal choice for players who enjoy simulation and strategy games. While the potential for repetitiveness exists, the game's attention to detail, customization options, and ongoing support from the developers make it a worthwhile investment for those looking to unleash their inner designer and house flipper.

The only thing that didn't convince me is the approval rating of the various buyers; it's pretty clear that each customer is triggered by one or two specific elements in a completely illogical way. 
For example, once you understand that a specific buyer is a flower lover, all you have to do is fill the house to be sold with flowers. Even if the house hasn't been cleaned and the toilet is missing, you can rest assured that this buyer will make false papers to get it.

In any case, I'm glad they decided to make a sequel, which I hope is even more beautiful and entertaining than this one.

House Flipper is an absolute gem of a game that offers a unique and incredibly satisfying experience for anyone with a penchant for creativity and home improvement. From the moment I started playing, I was drawn in by the game's immersive mechanics and attention to detail.

The ability to transform rundown properties into stunning, personalized living spaces is nothing short of addictive. Each task, whether it's cleaning up debris, painting walls, or arranging furniture, feels remarkably fulfilling, allowing you to witness tangible progress in real time. The game's realistic simulation of renovation work is not only educational but also strangely therapeutic, offering a sense of accomplishment that few other games can match.

One of the standout features of House Flipper is its vast array of customization options. From choosing paint colors to picking out the perfect kitchen cabinets, the level of control you have over the design process is truly impressive. The satisfaction of seeing your vision come to life as you turn a dilapidated dwelling into a stunning masterpiece is immensely gratifying.

Furthermore, the game's attention to realism extends beyond just the physical renovations. The financial aspects of property investment, such as buying and selling houses strategically, adds a layer of depth that keeps you engaged and constantly striving to improve your skills. The sense of progression and growth as you amass wealth and reputation is incredibly rewarding.

House Flipper's charming graphics and user-friendly interface enhance the overall experience, making it accessible to players of all ages and skill levels. The frequent updates and additional content introduced by the developers demonstrate their commitment to keeping the game fresh and exciting.

In conclusion, House Flipper is a delightful blend of creativity, strategy, and relaxation. Its addictive game-play, coupled with the joy of turning neglected spaces into dream homes, makes it an absolute must-play for anyone seeking a positive and immersive gaming experience. Whether you're a seasoned gamer or just looking to unwind after a long day, House Flipper offers endless hours of enjoyment and a unique sense of accomplishment.

Total Score: 9/10

[b]Graphics:[/b] Graphics do not have to be top-notch for a game to be enjoyable, and in this game such is the case. The graphics of this game are designed as such that the lower-end computers can handle the game, and though I have not yet tried it on my low-end laptop, I imagine that it will handle just fine. The only thing you need to worry about on lower-end computers is the load time, which might be significantly longer.

[b]Content - Decorating:[/b] This game has jobs you can complete for in-game currency and houses you can purchase with in-game currency to shape and decorate almost any way you want. You will need to complete a job to unlock the house for purchase, however, so do be aware of that. One of the major downsides to this content, however, is that you must acquire the Game Over achievement in order to purchase a house more than once. Additionally, if you have installed DLC before completing this achievement, you must also complete all DLC houses to get the achievement....which can get very painful if you have all of the DLC. The second downside to content is that almost all furniture in the game is "modernized." You may have to go searching through the Steam Workshop for things you want and hope there is something there...or design it yourself if you have the ability and talent to do so.

[b]Content - Build Your Own:[/b] If you want to build a house from scratch, or add onto existing houses, you must obtain the Farm DLC. There is no other way to get it done. The other downside? You are restricted to only three floors, cannot add basements at this time, and houses that already have roofs on them cannot have new floors added atop of them. The upside? The Farm DLC provides three empty plots of land on which to build massive houses and finally includes some not-as-modernized, farm-style furniture. Woohoo!

[b]Content - Pets:[/b] Yes, that is right. Pets are available in this game through the Pets DLC and through Farm DLC. You do have to purchase the DLC to get them, but the pets from Pets DLC will help you on your job sites.

[b]Content - Fishing:[/b] This is not a fishing game. This is a house flipping game. Fishing has nothing to do with house flipping. Why do you care about fishing in a house flipping game? Shoo! You are looking at the wrong game!

[b]Content: Buyers:[/b] The Buyers Problem is why one point is knocked off of the score. So, what is The Buyers Problem? Well, to put it simply, there are way too few buyers for houses. The AI is designed in this game so that buyers lean toward specific things in houses...which is great until you end up with the same two buyers at the top for just about every house even when you are sometimes placing into it things that should have more appeal to different buyers. The AI on this is still a bit wonky. The good news is that once you unlock the Game Over achievement, you need not worry so much about buyers any more. Design and plan to your hearts' content!

[b]Content- Profiles:[/b] This is one of the really neat features about this game. You can create multiple profiles on your account. Each profile is like a completely separate game, allowing each profile to complete all of the offered jobs and design the houses in the way that the user wishes. So, if you share an account with a sister, for example, each of you can have your own profile and do your own thing with a single account.

[b]Content - DLC:[/b] There are several DLCs available for this game, even including a Luxury one and an HGTV one, that add new items, jobs, and houses to the market for you to decorate. The downside is that these DLCs are not available for all platforms. If you play via Steam you are in luck, though! All DLC is available.

I enjoy playing this game, because oddly, it is really soothing to play. I boot this game up, put on a podcast or some music, and just go to town on a house. Reminds me of playing Viscera Cleanup Detail, or Hardspace Ship Breaker. Just a relaxing game where you can (nearly) be as creative as you want. I picked this game up because it seemed like such a strange concept, and I have grown to really like playing it here and there when ever I need to relax.

The only problems I have with the game are as follows: While you can build walls and knock them down, you can only do this to the walls already inside the house. You cannot construct additions to the building, or remove areas. It is a very small playground sometimes, unfortunately.

Why are you furnishing homes? This doesn't make any sense. When you sell a home, you don't include sofas and TVs and even cars. On top of that, the search mechanic for these items is not great. Many items aren't called what you would expect. Having tabs filled with items for different classifications of rooms (kitchen items, dinning room items, bathroom items, etc.) would be fantastic. Sadly, you have to sort through a lot of crap.

Why are there so few buyers? Why do I keep selling houses to these same people to live in? It is really quite strange. Having a setting where you can set expectations to random; and thus have to fulfill new and interesting conditions each time (can you possibly make this tiny house have what this person is looking for??) would keep it fresh and interesting.

A big problem I have with the game is the DLC. I have no problem with a game selling expansions after they have made a solid base game, it makes good business sense (note, I say a solid base game, which not all game developers do, sadly). The problem I have with it is that each DLC pack sells for almost as much as the base game itself. This feels extremely overpriced for what you actually get out of it, and just feels really greedy like they are trying to milk what they have as much as they can.

Because of this, as much as I have really enjoyed playing the game, I would only recommend it while it is on sale, the DLC especially.

[h1]Mechanics Are Fun for About an Hour[/h1]
...after that it's just tedious torture.

I got House Flipper (just the core game) when it was on sale, so it cost me almost nothing. I think they did this to try to get new players to buy their DLC. The problem is that all of the DLC is way more expensive. The one DLC-locked item that seems ridiculous not to have in the core game is a lawnmower. You get a [spoiler]flamethrower, but that's expensive to refuel and takes maybe 3 to 7 refills to clear overgrown grass from a property.[/spoiler] So you flip houses without really being able to mow down overgrown grass. Seems gimped.

Speaking of gimped, the LONG list of things you can't do or have no control over in House Flipper:
[list]
[*]Can't get all of the Steam Achievements unlocked unless you buy all of the DLC. W˥̄F? How evil can you get?
[*]Can't paint ceilings. And painting walls around windows takes more paint then painting other walls of the same size. Awkward.
[*]Can't paint walls different colors/textures horizontally (but there are a few textures to buy that do this)
[*]Can't destroy/move exterior walls. Which means you can't make your own property designs.
[*]Can't add/remove levels of a house.
[*]Can't relocate the main and rear entrances. On that note, can't add additional entrances.
[*]Can't sell to anyone except the same 10 pre-defined parties, i.e.: nothing random, same buyers who want the same things.
[*]Negotiation is stuck with the option "you ask for X money and seller either refuses or accepts", so you can't haggle at all. And the success of your negotiations seems to be completely random. $60k asks can fly while $2k asks might get denied.
[*]Can't make much money unless you not only flip houses but also become an interior decorator to appease buyers. Why does every single buyer prefer a pre-furnished house? That's not how house flipping works, lol. You can stage, but almost no one buys houses based on how many decorations are included with the house... except all of the House Flipper game's buyers apparently.
[*]So many bugs and awkward UI issues that you end up having to waste money in-game to get around those things. Examples: placed a shower in an orientation the devs didn't expect? Have to cancel your assembly, sell it, and buy another in their preferred orientation since you're stuck unable to click on anything during the assembly. Or perhaps you're trying to sell a hundred cups and dishes littered across a kitchen cabinet, and just miss one by a pixel and accidentally sell the entire kitchen cabinet? What you earned from selling it won't cover what you have to pay to put it back. Oops. Or selling junk on a window sill, but accidentally sell the window itself? Then you have to buy a new window, break out the wall again, etc. Geees. Users should be able to set a sell amount to trigger a warning yes/no dialog on the sell gun on the fly. That would be a good use of the mouse wheel to select between preset limits or to turn off the warning.
[*]It won't matter if you've spent time selecting the right, tasteful and/or elegant colors for walls, furniture, etc., because buyers don't care. You could throw down a hot pink sofa on top of a green carpet, in front of striped purple walls, and buyers will still pay the same price. Long story short: your style or palette decisions make no difference.
[*]Walls do not block line of sight, meaning you can clean the inside of the house from the outside and vice versa.
[*]Changing the assembly difficulty does nothing, as assembly steps still the same for many (most) items.
[*]Assembly of one shower might be super quick, while another is exponentially more tedious. Why? Makes no sense at all. Same with so many other items. One sink is a few clicks, and another is a tedious click-fest. There's no rhyme or reason to the assembly. I'm not even going to mention how out of touch with reality any of the assembly is since this is a game.
[*]Once you've mastered all of the skills, there's really no reason to keep using them. You can just clean up and flip a house with just your cleaning skill and make money and get the sell X number of houses achievement.
[*]Achievements are not localized, meaning to unlock anything with a monetary value in the achievement is set to Euro. So you're forced to change your money type to Euro if you want to track that.
[*]No grid or any assistance to help you line up placement of items. Good luck adding a dozen overhead ceiling lights and getting them lined-up to look perfect.
[/list]

I got all of the achievements in the core game except for the 'sell 50 houses'. I was about 30-some houses (easy to get), but I stopped when I realized all of the DLC is tied to the Steam Achievements, so you can never get 100% unless you buy their DLC. No thanks, time to uninstall and then remove it from my library permanently. But hey, at least for the super cheap price I paid for it, I did get some fun out of it for 70-some hours in decorating houses more than flipping them. But the mechanics of assembly, repairs, painting, and tiling become tedious over time. And then eventually you get tired of the limited furniture/decoration supplied.

My advice for those looking at this title for the first time many years after release: if you get it on sale and enjoy decorating and laying out houses, have some fun it, but don't bother with any of the DLC. Because by the time you get around to playing the DLC you're already tired of the game.

It's a terrific game concept. Sadly, the devs don't seem to care about issues that make the game VERY frustrating. They are too busy creating new content to fix the bugs that plague this game.

You buy houses cheap, fixing them up, then sell them to buyers. You are also offered jobs cleaning up, fixing, and renovating houses. This is a great way to not only make some money early in the game, but they also unlock additional features in the game. 

The buyers give you feedback (very poorly formulated and inaccurate feedback, often the same thing in both the negative and positive categories) to guide you regarding how you can increase the property value by tailoring things to their individual needs. Sadly, these include being told that a family needs 3 kids rooms, not just 2, then that there aren't kids' rooms. You can get rid of the kitchen, and the game still has feedback from a buyer that he doesn't need the kitchen. What kitchen?? In one house, a kitchen didn't even exist, ever! You add a bedroom, but there's still no bedroom. You have a ton of chifferrobes, dressers, etc, but a buyer will complain that there is no place to put his clothes. You can add a ton of storage to a house, yet every single room gives you the fresh feedback that there isn't room to store stuff, you add things, then OH! There's storage space. Next room, same thing all over again. When you delete the TV from the bedroom, the buyer will thank you and say now he can sleep in peace, but still have feedback complaining that there is a TV in the bedroom. 

The garden add-on: The text says that winning a garden contest you get a percent of the sales price. Instead of adding that to the sales price, it magically appears in your balance. There are several aspects that weren't thought through. The garden concepts are, let us say, interesting. Apparently the "typical" American garden has pine trees, a pool, and a grill. You need to have the internet description open for the gardens to get a decent amount of points on these.

The English is absolutely wretched in some cases and okay in others. A snow globe is labelled as a snowball, for example. The answer from the dev team is that you should work for free giving them your expertise. In my case, I use my 8 years of university training to get paid to clean-up people's English, translate between German and English, and write technical documentation, so why would I donate my time and expertise to a game that I paid money to play?

The dev team's concepts of what America and Americans are like is extremely odd. I say this as a military brat, who lived all over the US as a child (20 schools). The game seems to have been developed by Scandinavians, which would be great, if they hadn't chosen to set it in the USA. You'll find their requirements for rooms to qualify as a certain room type to be extremely frustrating. The forums are full of complaints regarding this topic.

The game would be fun and fulfilling, if you weren't struggling with so many bugs, trying to figure out what is meant with the language in so many places, and it didn't lag so hard. I have had to set the options down to nearly the lowest possible quality. I don't have this kind of lag with Skyrim.
I only played for 17 minutes because unfortunately it gave me motion sickness. Otherwise, decent game.

Usually in the kitchen for some reason, but I can rip out and replace entire heating/plumbing and AC systems, as well as knock out walls without regard to whether they're load-bearing. :( 

I would 100% pre-order House Flipper 2 *right now* if you would just let those be movable too. <3

Also, it would be handy to have a tool that shows measurements of some sort, or even just placement in relation to items around it so I don't have to remove and replace things when they aren't centered, because I need them to be centered. That would really put House Flipper 2 over the top for me.

If none of that bothers you, or you can accept it anyway, I'd definitely recommend this game!

Edit 31.07.2023:
I read many negative reviews lately because of all the bugs Farm DLC has - or is supposed to have. So I was very hesitant at first to buy the DLC. 
I dared to try anyways and after three or fours hours I can tell you that I have encountered, if any, only minor bugs. Sometimes the game seems to lag in reaction, for example I went outside, but my tool wheel was still showing the inside tools, so I had to go back in and out again to make the game realize where I am. That happened exactly ONCE. There are other such little things occasionally, but other than that, everything works fine. 
I've done a couple of jobs, I've worked on some of my own projects, and encountered no mayor problems. 
The game runs smoothly and I also have no issues with performance, even though I don't have a high-end gaming PC. 
It seems to me though that for some reason there are people who have a lot of issues whereas others don't have any. So if you were able to play the game without (bigger) problems, I'm confident Farm DLC will not break anything for you. 
That being said, the DLC brings many nice new things and tools. I actually like the grabbling hook (or what it's called), but I'd still love to be able to chance existing houses (not sure if this is supposed to work? But I couldn't change anything, or at least I haven't found out yet how). I have not yet tried the whole "your own farm" thing, but I will next time I play. 

(original review below)

If you have ever played the Sims and thought, why do I have to play with the avatar, just let me continue building houses (mansions... castles...), this game is totally for you.

Only this is much more realistic because you are IN the house and if this were in VR, you'd probably at some point wonder, why the hell did I give up my office job?! Unless, of course, your dream job always was to be a handiman or the like.

Yes, this gets repetitive after a while, but before it does, it gets addictive, so while you notice that the houses you can buy to renovate are the same ones you did before in your email jobs, it's still loads of fun to just, well, create. Create your dream house, get wild with the interior, put things where and how you usually never would (or your better half wouldn't let you...), try out colors and color combinations...

And whatever you do - have FUN. Because with this one, you definitely can.

It's relaxing, you can stop at any time, or you can spend hours upon hours with it. Gameplay and controls are simple after you've gotten the hang of it, graphics are great and realistic, and birds will sing for you... Well sometimes I turn the ambient volume down, I admit it, these critters are loud.

Only the buyers can be a bit annoying at times, because they comment on things that don't happen, or make no sense, because they complain about dirt while you are just in the progress of cleaning... but you learn to ignore them, do your thing, and sell just another house (must be the 20th...30th...50th or so) to the Donald Trump lookalike (seriously, he does).

Tl;dr - if you enjoy building and creating, just get it. You won't regret it.

After over 1,200 hours I finally decided to add my review. This is one of the most relaxing, fun, and stress-releasing games I've ever played. Funny thing is, I've never played through the game in full, as I mostly use the dev cheats to complete missions so I can be totally creative. First off, I love that they added that ability because my dream game was something like The Sims but being able to explore in first-person with realistic graphics. To say I love this game is an understatement. Even before Farm Flipper came out I was already using all kinds of community creations to make extensions. Farm Flipper just took it to a whole new level and now the houses I make are insane.
The concepts are endless with this game, and I can't wait for House Flipper 2 and to see what Frozen District has in store for us. Thank you guys for making my dream game!

This game is a very fun and easy to understand game.
The basic premise is that you make old/bad houses better and on face value that sounds boring but in this game it really isn't, there are multiple houses you can buy, renovate, sell etc and with all the items, paint, layout plans you can really make your self become a true house flipper.
At some times the game may feel a bit repetitive on some of the more bigger maps and it does take some time whilst working on the house flipping aspect of the game, especially if you're trying to get all the achievements it may be difficult to be able to get all of them because everyone has different things that they like and dislike.

Overall House Flipper is a fun game that makes what many see as a tedious task into a fun game where you can build the house of your dreams or a poorly built shack and that's what I think makes this game really shine out.

★★★★½ (5-star scale)

If you’re a Sims gamer who spends most of their time building/renovating houses, this game is for YOU.

What I like:
- The creative freedom when renovating and selling properties.
- All the choices in furniture, paint, wall/floor panels/tiles - there’s a lot to choose from (even with just the base game!)
- The game mechanics are easy to get used to.
- I like the email messages that clients send you. Their stories add a personal touch.

Updates I hope to see eventually (especially for the second game coming out!):
- I wish the loading screens that pop up when you enter properties were updated to show the progress you made so far. It’s kind of annoying looking at a picture of what a property used to look like - with torn up furniture, dirt on the walls, and trash everywhere. I want to be reminded of all the hard work I’ve put in when continuing a project!
- I wish the before & after photos feature was included in the base game. You need the HGTV DLC to have this. :( There’s also not enough before & after pictures that get taken, in my opinion. I’ve ended up just snapping some screenshots of my own.

Overall, this is a solid cozy and relaxing game to play while listening to some music, a podcast, or audiobook. Super intrigued to see what the second game will be like! But for now, I’m happy to play this one for hoursss.

2023 Review Edit:

I love all of the new DLC that has been added since I made my original review!  Lots of beautiful houses, colors, and decor to play around with, and I'm glad they made it where you can change stairs, at least in the newer homes.  

The Pet DLC is cute, although for a while there the pets would get stuck on floors, unable to go up and down the stairs before they added their ability to "teleport" up and down.  Cats weren't able to use the wall cat furniture for a while, but now they can.  The pets do still get stuck in places every now and then, which spams the "pet can't reach location" error, but it seems to happen less than before.

The only complaint that I have now is that the game is MASSIVE, which causes a lot of lag, freezing, and crashes.  Fully installed and actively played, this game takes up more space than my MMORPGS and lengthy open world RP games, and because of this I only install it when I'm actively playing it.  It's weird that the space used goes down when I uninstall and reinstall the game, even though nothing inside the game has changed.  I'm not sure if it's holding onto every single auto-save the game performs, but that's the only thing I can think of.

I have the upcoming House Flipper 2 game on my wish list, and hope that it comes with improvements on compression to take up less space and have less lag and crashes.

I still recommend this game, I only suggest that players maybe not hold onto as many houses as I do, since I've noticed the lag is a bit less when I have less "owned" houses.  I love to flip back and forth between houses and try different things with each, so I always have a few of my favorite houses/floor plans to do so.

__________________________________________________________________________

I love this game.  It's relaxing to take a house that is in rough shape, clean it up, repair it, and make it look amazing, inside and out.  The garden package is great too as you can really spruce the place up and give it great appeal to buyers, or keep it for yourself.  ;)

However, there's a few complaints that I have.  First, there are some walls that you just can't tear down, no matter how much you'd like to, and it's not limited to the exterior walls, which would be nice to build onto a house.  Second, you cannot change the appearance of the stairs in any house, and the wood does not match floor options that you have.  This is made even uglier if the stairs have a runner carpet as those are always dated looking and clash with most all of the options you have, especially if you prefer a modern look.  And third, some houses have cars in their garages, but not all of them.  And while you can move these cars around or sell them, you can't buy a car to replace it or to put in any of the other garages of houses without cars.  I know that's just a minor annoyance and doesn't really affect the house restoration, but it's just something that would be nice to have!  Honestly it wouldn't bother me if there had been no houses with cars, but when they dangle that out there and don't offer it as an option for other homes, or alternative vehicles to park in all these empty garages, it makes me sad.  :'(

TL;DR: Overall, 8.8/10. After about 45 hours in the game, I can say House Flipper is worth playing for its relaxation factor and the satisfaction you get from cleaning/fixing things. If you're like me and love checklists, turning messes into masterpieces, and discovering your creative side, you'll love this game. Super excited for the second one! It looks even better.

House Diversity: 8/10
Decoration Options: 9/10
User Interface: 8/10
Bug-free: 9/10
Graphics & Sound Design: 10/10
Controls: 9/10

HOUSE DIVERSITY. Mostly, there are quite a few options. For the base game, though, some of the quests can be really repetitive (I think I got the same house for Christmas at least 3 times). At that point it's just work, not fun. But I enjoyed the others, especially ones from the Luxury and HGTV DLCs. Those were a lot of fun and had many more options for house type, location, work orders, etc.

DECORATION OPTIONS. For the most part, there is a wide range of things to choose from, especially if you get the DLCs (I got Luxury, Cyberpunk, HGTV, and Apocalypse). However, some items I just didn't quite jive with, and I couldn't find options for what I wanted in a certain house (i.e., not enough tall openable window options, and can't modify/build roofs). This could be a feature I hope they add in the future or to its sequel. Overall, though, I made some spaces I really enjoyed and felt at home in.

USER INTERFACE. Easy to use and looks pretty good, though I'd add better functionality to the shop so you could exit/go back more smoothly between pages. It's also really hard to tell what items look like in the store, and you can't always preview them properly. The paint is the worst - I had to buy all the shades of a color just to figure out what was already painted in a house (I never found the right shade).

BUGS. Overall, smooth game. There were a few issues I ran into, but none were game breaking that I recall. In any case, it wasn't significant enough for me to remember!

GRAPHICS & SOUND DESIGN. Though it's an older game, it looks and sounds good. It's satisfying to look at the furniture and textures, especially the modern styles. The music is nice to listen to and not as repetitive as some games, though eventually I did turn it off. The cleaning and painting sounds are really satisfying, too - it's almost ASMR for people who love tidying.

CONTROLS. Pretty intuitive and smooth. I like that you can improve your skills and therefore paint/build/modify multiple wall pieces at a time. One thing I disliked at times was that placement was a little off - some things would be just barely off-centered (I'd pull my hair out), or I couldn't get things to line up, or items just wouldn't fit in a room. Their sizing needs to be adjusted a bit better to fit things in the rooms.

I bought this game on somewhat of a whim.  I'd read a few reviews, watched a few videos and decided to give it a go.  I'm so glad that I did!  I've enjoyed a few other simulator games, but none like this - I'm addicted!  Want a rose garden?  Plant one!  Want an amazing yard?  Landscape to your wee heart's content!  Don't like the interior layout?  Change it up!  I love having a plethora of options and variations on the old standards.  
I've always had a design/decorating bug, and now I get to feed that need, as often as I like.  I also have a new  (and so far very effective!) OCD tamer.  I find myself eager to see new listings, and I get impatient between houses, because there's always something else that comes to mind for the next project.  I haven't had such a level of excitement and eagerness to carry on, in a very long time, and I greatly enjoy feeling that way about a game, again.
Highly recommend.  =^.^=
