If you like the decorating parts of The Sims and Animal Crossing, this is for you. I loved those, so this was perfect for me.

First, you renovate a house to make it look awesome to your tastes, and you barely make any money. Then you figure out what the buyers are into, and you figure out how to game the system to maximize your profits. You no longer feel like you're renovating houses, but this is what flipping houses is IRL too, right? A nice unintentional commentary on ruining historical homes from the 20's through 40's to sell to the tasteless with inheritance housing funds. Once you've sold all the houses and have more money than you'd ever need, you can re-buy the houses and make them suited to your own personal tastes again.

People online seem to love the Pets and the Farms/Garden DLCs. I skipped those and went for the HGTV one and Luxury (because I really wanted to do the Yacht). They were worth it. I don't know who those HGTV weirdos are but the houses are neat that they've added, I like that we get some older colonial-style architecture. I don't like pets or gardening so I'm gonna keep skipping those.

The architecture in this game feels very restrictive. My dream would be to renovate (in-game, not IRL) Craftsman homes from the 20s, the Sears homes from the 30s, and the wartime 40's duplexes you find in major US cities that existed before, well, California. No shotgun shacks either, which feels wasted. I also love the 60's and 70's style one-story bungalows that are noticeably absent from this game as well. The colonial homes from the HGTV expansion are nice but I feel like we're missing a huge slice of Americana with this. The homes in the base game feel very samey to me. Apparently the Farms expansion lets you build your own homes from scratch, so I may need to get that.

If you love the decoration aspect of the sims and animal crossing nh you will love this game. Many many great accessories in many many colors and patterns :3. Overall 8/10, I have many small criticisms but it is a solid decorating sim. My main criticism is that virtually everything is brightly colored. "Dark red" more closely resembles a solo cup than blood. "Dark green" is medium green. Betrayal, agony, hatred, death. Not great if you appreciate muted tones. Not enough dark stains for wood. Not a great vector for maximalism; its hard to make piles/stacks of objects, it's usually impossible. Menuing is a skill you must learn. Eventually you will remember how they sort things. I wish there were more filters for all the categories, but see as there are easily dozens of unique types of furniture/decor, I am more than satisfied with what is present :]. I would highly appreciate more older aesthetics to be offered instead of solely late 20th-21st century designs with exactly one set of Victorian-inspired furniture. Wooden trim/molding is not available, only in painted shades of white/grey/beige.

Great game to get on sale, I only bought the base game that came with the free bunker and cyber DLCs. I found the beginning to be very boring but after getting through all the "busywork" jobs and now buying and flipping actual houses, the game feels much more involved and creative. I usually spend about an hour per house. There's also some really fun houses referencing other games and pop culture to explore. As a side tip for those achievement hunting, make sure to change your in-game currency to Euro if you're from the US, as the achievements track in Euros and not dollars- I negotiated a sale for over $50k per the achievement, but it didn't trigger because the exchange rate is different. Overall I think this game is pretty decent and there is a lot you can do in it.

How to make Cookies 

Ingredients
120g butter, softened
75g light brown sugar
75g golden caster sugar
1 medium egg
1 tsp vanilla extract
180g plain flour
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
150g dark chocolate, cut into chunks

Method
STEP 1
Heat oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4 and line two baking sheets with parchment. Cream the butter and sugars together until very light and fluffy, then beat in the egg and vanilla. Once combined, stir in the flour, bicarb, chocolate and ¼ tsp salt.

STEP 2
Scoop 10 large tbsps of the mixture onto the trays, leaving enough space between each to allow for spreading. Bake for 10-12 mins or until firm at the edges but still soft in the middle – they will harden a little as they cool. Leave to cool on the tray for a few mins before eating warm, or transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Will keep for three days in an airtight container.

PROS

-Decent value, many hours of gameplay and replayability.
-A wonderful way to find a creative outlet or just relax.
-A large and varied workshop with new designs/furniture/decorations to download.
-Devs that are active and involved. We get constant updates, new content, improvements, competitions and player input.
-Great DLCs.
-Unique gameplay.
-Plenty of different properties to flip.

CONS

-UI can be a bit funky at times, but they've been slowly improving it.
-You can't build your own house from scratch. You can add or break interior walls, however the outside walls cannot be moved, only decorated.
-You can't visit previous houses you've flipped unless you don't sell, but you can replay old jobs.
-It's highly recommended you play with the DLCs, as the quality of decorations and furniture is significantly higher.
-If you want to run the game to look pretty, your pc is gonna get HOT.
-The buyer needs are a bit strange to design for at times, but personally I just ignore this feature and design what I want.

House Flipper is my current favorite game.  I've played on steam and another game platform since 2021 and I prefer the version here on Steam.    I am not a regular gamer, I do not play shooting games for example, because I am not good at that and the learning curve stresses me out.    House Flipper is great for me because there is no time limit, I can be creative with lovely things.  I am not as concerned about the selling part of the game as I am about creating a great property.     This is almost a meditative exercise for me.   I would recommend House Flipper to others who just want to chill out while making a beautiful virtual place.

Hi at all,

this is a little gem to enjoy and relax while still doing something good.
You can be creative, clean, destroy, buy houses for your own or to gain money and there is a lot of cute events bond to happen (if you buy DLC´s).

But listen guy´s! There is soon House Flipper 2 to come out!!!
It will be better in Quality and there will be more realistic way´s of cleaning, easier way of changing color´s more stuff to pick and place etc. And a Sandmode to build a house from the very beginning.

So choose wisely if you wanna play a game with some not perfect gaming abilitie´s or a game where you can place everything everywhere etc?

I could not wait, I tryed very long to wait and after I read the next is coming out with better placing ability´s I wanted to wait. even more.. but as you can see I could not endure it anymore.

After 31 hours of playing I am happy, this is a game I play when I just don´t know what else to play.
You have many color´s to pick from you can put lots of things on the table of your customer and realize that his home is way more beautiful than your own and that you totally forgot to keep in mind how much you gain for this job and what you invested in his house.^^

Of course you beginn in a "little house" that doesn´t look like much it´s still charming^^
You get to know the mechanic stepp by stepp and with dlc´s a bit hard to make decesion where do I go first.

My advice:
1. Go in the Settings and change the way of how you clean the window (yes you start as a cleaner).
Add it to your mouse speed.
2. Change the automatic save to "30 Min" to avoid little bugs or the feeling that your game may crush.
But remember to always go over Exit Game and say "Yes save and close down".
3. There is a variety to pick "hands" from.
Very funny when its hallooween or christmas just take your time and look around.
4. If you can´t handle the look of Cockroaches you can change their appearance to glas.
5. The Dev´s still support their game with new DLC´s and items!
(In the workshop you will find tons of things too, the maker did a quite good job! Cheer to community^^)
6. Press F on the keyboeard to activate your flash! (The game told me too but only after I had the third night job done^^)
7. The DEV still support this game with DLC´s some extra for Event´s like Christmas etc.

There is so much I could tell you but than we would never be able to stopp talking^^
Look at some screenshots or youtube video and wait till an event comes so it´s cheaper if you end up buying it like me, wink.

Thanks for the Dev´s whisper I found this new game "Honeycomp" and added it to my poor wishlist.

IThx for this game and wish all who will buy or already have lots of gaming fun.

I was so excited to play House Flipper, a game where you can buy, renovate and sell houses for profit. I thought it would be a relaxing and satisfying experience, like watching HGTV on steroids. But boy, was I wrong. Everything was fine until I had to paint the walls. That's when the nightmare began. The paintbrush was so hard to control, it felt like I was trying to draw with a wet noodle. The paint ran out so fast, I had to keep buying more cans. And worst of all, the game didn't recognize when I had finished painting a room, so I had to keep going over the same spots until it finally registered. It was a waste of time and money, and I hated every minute of it. Do yourself a favor and avoid this game like the plague. But i recommend this game for you jobless out there. (5/10)

I bought this game on impulse while it was on sale, and it has quickly become one of my favorites.  If you are the kind of person who will spend ages in The Sims building and decorating houses, this will scratch a similar itch.

The controls are easy to learn.  The jobs in game serve as a tutorials to show what you can do with your tools, as well as helping you to earn money to buy houses and maybe giving you a few ideas.  There are all kinds of settings, including being able to change certain disgusting insects into pieces of glass, as well as a heads-up that this setting is available shortly before you have to deal with said problem for the first time.

There are times where it may feel a bit monotonous-- clean another window, scrub more dirt off the floor.  I actually enjoy putting on some music or a podcast to listen to while I play, to make things go quicker, especially for the more fiddly jobs.

Definitely recommend!

I am editing my first review, now with over 726 hours of gameplay experience and multiple playthrough, I have seen the highs and lows of this virtual renovation simulator.  I'll discuss the overall game and the DLC's and the recent issues. 

[b] Initial Impression and Gameplay [/b]

When I first purchased House Flipper, I was immediately captivated by its fun and rewarding gameplay mechanics.  The satisfaction of transforming run-down properties into beautiful homes kept me hooked for hours on end.  With four successful playthroughs under my belt, I can confidently say that the game offers a substantial amount of content to keep players engaged. 

[b] The Garden DLC [/b]

The Garden DLC stand out as a valuable addition to the game, providing an array of enjoyable outdoor tasks, such as mowing lawns, planting flowers, and designing picturesque landscapes.  The added jobs and customisation options offer a fresh perspective on home renovation, enhancing the overall gameplay experience.  If you enjoy beautiful outdoor spaces, the Garden DLC is a worthwhile investment. 

[b] The HGTV DLC [/b]

While the HGTV DLC introduced exciting new jobs and choices, it fell slightly short of expectations.  The houses and choices available lacked the visual appear and variety anticipated.  Nevertheless, the DLC still provided some enjoyable moments, even if it didn't quite live up to its potential.  If you're a dedicated fan of House Flipper, it may be worth exploring the HGTV DLC for it's unique tasks and challenges. 

[b] Luxury DLC [/b]

The Luxury DLC fell somewhat short in delivering the expected level of opulence.  While the new features were enjoyable, the lack of extensive furniture, flooring, and wall options restricted the true luxurious experience.  Despite this, the DLC did offer amazing houses that are worth flipping. 

[b] Pets DLC [/b]

This is my favourite DLC, it delivered its promise of adorable animals and well-designed houses.  The addition of pets adds an extra layer of charm and emotional connection to the game. It is definitely one of the DLC's worth investing in for a heartwarming and delightful experience. 

[b] Technical Issues and Concerns [/b]

While House Flipper initially provided a smooth and enjoyable gameplay experience, the addition of the workshop feature has introduced some maintenance issues.  Even with a limited number of workshop items, the game suffers from extended loading times, severe lag, and occasional crashes.  Deleting workshop items seemed to alleviate these problems, but it's disheartening to see the game's performance decline over time.  Moreover, recent reports of crashes, lags, and unaddressed issues in the Farm DLC indicate a concerning trend, leaving players to question the developer's commitment to resolving these technical issues,  as I do personally believe they are focusing on House Flipper 2 they are attempting to put out by next year.  

[b] Conclusion [/b]

House Flipper offers an engaging and satisfying renovation experience, with DLCs like the Garden and Pets providing substantial value and enjoyable content.  However, the game's overall experience has been marred by recent technical issues and lack of prompt resolutions.  It is disheartening to witness the game's decline as the developer shifts focus to House Flipper 2.  Hopefully, the developers will address these concerns and ensure that House Flipper maintains its status as an exceptional home renovation simulator. 

Final Score: 7/10

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2022 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I wouldn't have played this for closer to 900 hours if I didn't like it a lot.

A lot of freedom to be creative, and working on houses/gardens is highly rewarding as the result of the work is immediately visible.

Lots of jobs to do, and you can always re-do them later, if you want. I've never gotten to the point where I'd have sold all of the houses once (they have kept adding houses, making it more and more time-consuming), but one day I will manage it.

Some minor bugs persists, but they are mostly related to the buyers and I nothing I have encountered has been a real issue.

Update July 2023: Approaching 1000 hours played, and with new stuff from DLC (I suggest getting them on sale if you want them) the game has more possibilities and replay value than ever before.

As fun a concept as this is, gameplay-wise it doesn't differentiate itself all that much from regular commercial interior design modeling/visualization software, nor does it add enough QOL features, visual appeal and usablity over those to not become a bit of a bore very quickly.

This game for me has the Sims model of game purchasing. If you aren't gonna get the DLC just don't get the game. Most of the fun of flipping houses comes from the DLC content and honestly that doesn't really affect my review.
I played 16 hours of the game (almost straight with a 2 hour nap between 8 hour sessions) without the DLC. I just picked it up after I looked it up and realized I couldn't cut my grass without the DLC. The last 3 hours (posted at 18.9 hours btw) have opened my eyes to the fact that just like the sims everything is cut off by expensive DLC. It isn't awful though the base game without the DLC's is fun for probably 20-30 hours but if you wanna get indepth into the gameplay loop and really experience it you really do need that stuff. The DLC's do add missions that are fun as hell ngl but alot of the stuff just feels like it should be in base game (IE; Grappling hook, scaffolding, lawnmower). But besides those flaws the game is fun for what it is, build dream houses for yourself and your friends and flip them to make a profit or just keep them to take cool screenshots of. Its 3d sims without the character creator. Honestly I love it but you might not because of the price tag so just beware.

Enjoyable, a little buggy at times, and also a little tedious if you don't thoroughly enjoy remodeling homes and gardens. If you do find that enjoyable though this game is for you. Especially if you get all of the expansion packs, though I would recommend waiting until they go on sale as I find that they're a little over priced normally for what they are and what they bring to the main game. Where the main gameplay loop is fairly solid in its completed state there are several jobs in the dlc where things can get a little wonky. 

The pets in the pet dlc sometimes get stuck in the ground, and become uninterruptible unless you send them to the hotel and retrieve them. Something similar happens with the farm animals in the Farm DLC but they get outside of the fence boundary and can sometimes walk through solid objects. 

I found the Farm and Pets dlc's a little strange to add into this particular game. The pets are very cute and are enjoyable in small doses, but I don't find that they add anything to my gameplay. The Farm DLC is even stranger asking you to run a farm, grow crops and raise animals, a far departure from renovating houses. 

TLDR: Over all a very enjoyable game as long as you enjoy cleaning up virtual messes and renovating homes. Animals are a little weird but nothing too game breaking.

A fun game to play. I recommend it. While you're here, Please enjoy this pie recipe:
Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 brown sugar
4. 1/2 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples -peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double crust pie
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F ( 220 degrees C )
2. Combine butter , white sugar ,brown sugar, water , cinnamon and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside
3- Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices
4. Roll out top crust into 10 inch circle. Cut into 8 ( 1-inch ) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie,coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F ( 175 degrees C ) and bake until the crust is golden brown , the caramel on the top is set and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing

Pros.

Easy on the eye graphics.
Simplistic game design.
Sound design is peaceful.
Very mellow and chilled game to play.
Very relaxed atmosphere and mindless chilling.

Cons,

The fact that when you buy this game you are getting 1/4 of the content.
3/4 of the content is locked behind PAID DLC.
You can produce a lovely house, all be it with limited options, but lovely, but if you want to do the garden, even mow the lawn, yup, gotta pay for the DLC.
That's right kids, you have to pay, to mow grass in an already pricey game.
The content in the base game is repetitive as are the options for decoration.
DLC content is shown when renovating as a sly way to get you to buy.

Avoid if you have any morals, what a shame.

I really wish I could give this a recommendation but with how this game works and how limited it in actuality is, is quite the downer. It's okay - but that's about it.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+ You get to furnish homes
+ Items can be rotated in almost any way you want
+ Quite a bit of items
+ Ability points that make it possible to work faster and more efficiently

[b]Cons:[/b]
- gets repetitive very easily
- assembling of items is just click & hold (actual active participation like mini-games would make it more fun maybe, or even needing to rotate your mouse or something - just SOMETHING)
- Window cleaning is very wonky (why can't we just clean them with the damn mop)
- no freedom in customer jobs (I wanna make houses prettier, not uglier - thank you)
- a lot of the patterns are outright hideous (my condolences)
- shop categories are weirdly scattered
- paint colors are missing from their respective categories, but can be found from the overall paint category
- colors wrongly titled (pink being purple, green being yellow etc.)
- main dude walks over anything and everything, getting stuck between a lamp and a coffee table
- items don't move along the furniture they're on top of, they just fall down and you gotta rearrange them again
Ok game, but control and automation are bad. Placing things one at a time can become very tedious.

I really really didn't want this review to be bad, but...
Starting off, on the first levels I said that this game is one of the most relaxing games, also bought some DLC after finished the main game. But god, this game shouldn't left early, this game should be in some alpha or smth. Besides the poor optimization this game has(because fuck it, I can play it on 50 fps on 2070), these are some of the worst mood-killers of this game:
- crashes, it crashes a lot
- when exploring the map, sometimes it gets stuck and won't move
- when placing items from inspirations, they disappear, sometimes they are marked even as placed
- placing doors doesn't really register them inside the room
- placing tiles, sometimes it will place them on the other room, ruining its painting
- after placing an item from inspiration, the recommendation circle still remains and the item appears like it wasn't placed at all(yeah, I really wanted to do 100% on all jobs, but couldn't because of this bug)
- when gardening and digging, you always have to press E to dig for EACH plant, it means that when you have 20 plants in a row, you cannot shovel them all, you always have to press E before each plant, WITH THE SHOVEL IN THE HAND LOL, at least hide it
- and much more little things which personally, it annoyed me and made me write this review.

NOTE: It's not always happening, but it's starting to get really frustrating because I want to play this game to relax, not to annoy me. And most of the bugs appeared after the installation of the DLCs, they should firstly fix the bugs, THEN RELEASE another DLC. Also saw in some reviews that the dev team consists in 10 persons, but that doesn't matter, you assume this, you keep the game in alpha until it's good enough.

Putting these bugs aside, things that mattered the most to me were:
- great graphics(especially the lighting, it looks stunning)
- a very large variety of items and colors
- love the way you can customize your own home/garden
- something which other games do not have, that's why I kept playing in the first place

Overall, the game should've stayed in early(don't even know if it even was) and warning its users that sometimes, the game doesn't really work like a game. I hope that House Flipper 2 will be better, because without those little bugs, the game would be perfect.

EDIT  1: After writing this review, I jumped into the game, guess what, it got stuck when loading a mission LOL.

EDIT 2: Ah it seems that I cannot play that mission anymore, it just keeps getting stuck in loading screen when resuming a mission from Luxury pack. Also saw on internet that I wasn't the only one. Great.

i have an interface suggestion, which is that i wish the eyeview camera was a wider angle one. especially when working with large objetcs (ie. pool), the camera angle is smaller than the object itself so i don't know where i'm going or where to decently place the object. (in the garden dlc, there are green-glowing specified slots in which you have to place certain objects. i have had to sell the pool i had just installed because it falls out of the area, which is because i can't see where i'm walking to begin with)
i understand that maybe the camera is at such an angle to represent the human eye as realistically as possible, but realistically speaking it doesn't take me three digs and a click to install a pool. so maybe sometimes it's helpful to stretch the concept 'realistic'.
given all of this, the game is one of my all time favorites. never change!!!! (except the camera thing)

Maybe it's my computer and simultaneously my desire for something faster and more engaging, but I did not have a good time with this game. 

I was running it on high settings, which given my hardware (5700X processor and AMD 6600 GPU) I thought would be acceptable. Game frequently tanked in framerate when opening various UI elements, which is really weird because I would think those might be the least demanding elements, but that's one aspect I didn't like. The gameplay felt too slow. Picking up items takes too long for me to find any joy in rearranging and organising stuff, cleaning feels fine but painting feels even slower. 

Those sections where you install and repair stuff like radiators or electrical sockets, most of them I can skip by holding the mouse button down. I thought there'd be puzzle elements when I first saw these where I'd have to memorise how these are put together, but no, I just hold a mouse button - very non-engaging. Personally, I'd either have them be fully interactable or have an option to skip this altogether. Perhaps the option to have them complete themselves by just holding down a button is more accessible to those with motor disabilities, but it takes tooooo loooong for me, personally.

Maybe behind all of this there is truly an immersive game, maybe the other reviews are truly genuine about that. But, personally, I've played about an hour of it and was sick and tired and decided to get a refund, 'cause clearly I wasn't going to enjoy it any further.

Got it on sale for $8 and it is more than worth it, imo.

There's a lot of initial renovations and jobs for you to do to get a good hang of the game. I feel like there's plenty of variety in the problems and what people are looking for also. Of course, there's nothing super crazy and out there with just the base game, but I've had a lot of fun. I didn't encounter many bugs, just one obvious one. If the house had a bathroom with fixtures already there (shower, sink, toilet) it would all teleport outside of the house. You would need to go in and manually sell those original ones and replace them, but it wasn't a big deal to me, just annoying when I liked the set up of the original room and suddenly it's gone.

Adding things from the workshop has also elevated this game to a huge degree. I love the creativity and almost sandbox feel you can get from buying and selling your own homes, but being able to get objects and stuff from the workshop and create even more diversity has been super fun.

People have said this game can get repetitive. Maybe if you let it. I choose to do things like purposefully design a modern style home or a ranch home just to enjoy a cohesive vision and each house gets a garden of some kind, etc. You can always knock down walls in a house you've been in many times and somehow make it different. Replace all the windows and it feels like a whole new place. It's up to you, and that's why it's so fun.

Let me explain House Flipper:
1. House dirty
2. *mop noises*
3. House clean
OR THAT’S WHAT THE GAME WANTS YOU TO THINK
It’s a slippery slope from “I want to remove that can from this kitchen floor” to “Damn this room could really use some teal heron wallpaper matched with sea breeze paint and a cool oak dresser”
This game made me buy an expansion pack that allows me to mow lawns. I own a virtual lawnmower. My own mother came and asked me for something and I said “hold up let me just mow this lawn” and she looked at me like I was out of my mind. I am out of my mind. I could be playing house flipper right now.
But if you think this is just a relaxing renovation game then think again, for you are rewarded if you sell to every possible buyer and Giorgio wants two baths and no kitchen so I made a house with two baths and no kitchen and THE LOVELY ELDERLY COUPLE STILL BOUGHT IT. I made a nice house for the young couple with the baby and it was bought by Dolan Trund. Yes. Dolan Trund. I also essentially sold a sex dungeon to a man called Jimmy Traitor who whenever I place a child’s object in any house I am building tells me “Those aren’t my kind of toys”. 
I’m forever struggling to understand why the one potted cactus makes the house instantly more appealling to the “I like creative disaster” woman and why everybody is so horny about bookshelves, why the room that has been a living room for the past half an hour is suddenly classed as a kitchen oh god Giorgio’s pissed at me again.
Lovely and relaxing and calming I may say, but then again they give you a hammer and there are walls, you can take out *whatever you like on them*. You can knock all of the walls down, you can sell the doors, you can sell the WINDOWS, you can make the worst house in the history of houses ever created and the AIs will still buy it for a profit.
I built a house and filled it with baths. Just baths. Only baths. It was chaotic. It was brilliant. Jimmy Traitor bought it? What does he want with all these baths? Is 2 the limit for Giorgio?
Let’s not even speak about the gardening DLC in which you are graded on coverage and variety of plants which increases the house sales price yes I’d like to mention the £200,000 profit I made on a property because I *ran around their lawn randomly placing daffodils for an hour* Oh and forget the confusing logic behind the animal crossing shovel, the house flipper shovel has SEEN THINGS. 
But seriously, I love this game so much, it has so many different things going for it and you can be as chill or as serious as you want to be. I am freed from the shackles of powerwashing and fully invested in real estate. As somebody who currently can’t do too much because of illness this game… I mowed the lawn mum.
If you need a new game to play and are looking for something different, a little slower maybe, I would recommend this game. FYI it is a bit pants without the DLC but still very playable and enjoyable.
Thanks for coming to my TEd Talk ✌🏻

As I stare next to the trash next to me, (you know, the trash that's overflowing the bag so much, I can no longer see the bag) I'm annoyed at how satisfying this game is. Obvious the game is fantasy and a total work of Fiction.

But... It does seriously make me consider buying a vacuum, a mop, and an actual trash can to put trash bags IN. I might actually take out the trash that's been building up for an... amount of time too embarrassing to type, even WITH the anonymity of the internet.

I'm even considering cleaning the windows, which has over 8 years of oil built up from vaping. (strange that the walls don't get that, still beats smoking)

and maybe... JUST maybe... I'll finally get the 10 years of spiderwebs clung to the ceiling, layered so thick, that it's as if a single web spans the entire house.

But most likely I'll let it keep building up while I play video games. I live alone, this is more important.

I decided to delete my review from 2021 and give a new one because I've bought and played all the DLCs since my last review. To this point I've played 333 hours on this game, spent over 30 hours on a farmhouse over the last few days, so I feel I can be more helpful now. 

I think this is probably my favourite game, especially with the creations of Workshop Items (thank you, House Flippers!)
With the addition of the DLCs there is so much that a player can get lost in, whether its doing jobs for others or renovating your own houses (most of my game play has been spent remodelling and selling houses, with very little focus on the jobs, meaning i've still got hours of game content to get to.)

I really want to give the creators a huge nod, they've created a great game, they have a sense of humour with it, they're very attentive to their player base, they're open to feedback and will develop ideas based upon said feedback, whilst communicating about updates. Great!

The DLCs definitely make the game better and add a lot more content, they're on sale so often it's worth purchasing them when you're able to. I'd recommend Farm and Garden Flipper for sure, since the garden is a different design vibe and it's fun. 

The Architect tool is a welcome addition, renovating buildings like Burnt House is a lot more enjoyable because it's not so restrictive thanks to the extra rooms and floors players can add, I was finally able to build an appropriate home for the family of 6! 
Architect also deserves points for ease of use (I should mention I use an xbox controller with my laptop whilst playing this game) and it feels like any other straightforward interface because it could have been awful.

Overall. this is an in-depth, well thought out game, particularly if you're someone that thinks having a To Do List is fun haha! The limits to creativity is down to the player's imagination, the game facilitates numerous ways to approach a renovation creatively, so the length of time spent on a house is up the the individual. 

 This is the nudge for those undecided if they want this game....*booming voice* yes you do, it is worth it and it is a lot of fun and you won't regret it. Do it. Do. It. 

Last fan boy comment - I bloomin' LOVED the Silent Hill house and the Breaking Bad house!! I'm sure there are more references sprinkled throughout the game but the I have so much respect to the developers for that, I was super excited to recreate that home.

Cons / Feedback
I think the roof tool needs some work, it would be better if we could play around with different shapes, or at least paint the underside of the roof so that the overhang isn't bright white. I suspect that's in the pipeline though, knowing how intuitive these developers are.

On the store page - it would be handy to have the 'Last purchased' and 'Recently viewed' fixed to the appropriate store page for items. For example, if I use the Renovation Shop, I would only like to see 'Last purchased' and 'Recently viewed' items from the Renovation category, not mixed amongst sofas and light switches. Vice versa for items purchased in the Interior Design tab. 

I would like to see more variations of curtain styles, whilst the ones in the game are beautiful, they're pretty much the same  styles with a tiny difference. Plus, the Workshop curtains tend to bug when placed in game and can't be opened or closed.  I'd also like to place curtains on any wall, not specifically above a window of corresponding size, this will allow curtains to be used as archways instead of the traditional wooden ones.

The Before/ After pics!! Probably my most disliked element of this game. I wish we were able to set up angle points or frames for the B/A pics because if you forget to take a pic on the in-game tablet, you might as well say goodbye to any decent portfolio shots. 
For example, you gut out and renovate a grubby little house into a masterpiece of a home by adding walls, changing the layout etc, the After shot will be a close up of a wall you installed. Or certain rooms won't be pictured at all and it's so disappointing after spending hours creating a home you're proud of only for the B/A to completely mess up the grand reveal. If you want to go back and look at your portfolio? It's the same terrible in-game pics that you're left with, so I hope you have a good memory.

Lighting - I wish we had more lighting options. Sometimes the design is what you want but the lampshade makes the light come out in jagged lines or boxes, they emit next to no light or they're brighter than the Sun. I wish we could toggle through 'dim/ med/ bright' options because we're also quite limited with choices, given that workshop lights can't currently function in game. 

The Buyers - The buyers are a great guide to have, encouraging players to build family homes to survival bunkers, however, they're annoying. 
They can simultaneously love and hate something about the house... how? and how do i fix it? No clues given. 
It's the same handful of people buying houses, too, the elderly couple own most of the real estate in my game, so it becomes tedious, alternatively, you're spending time creating homes that you don't really like in order to persuade a new buyer purchase one. 
Presumably, if we build it exclusively the way we want, disregarding the demands of the buyers, then the negative points from the buyers will reduce the final offer price? I'd rather a selection of 20 buyers, in which they have more simplistic preferences that are easier to discern. 

The Garden Contest - I wish I was able to submit a nice garden I've made without assigning it to one of the specified categories. Sometimes I'm really proud of the gardens I make but they don't quite fit into any of the categories. so I may only get 25% increase, even though it's a really well made garden. Maybe a more generalised category or additional specific categories so we can spread our wings a little further. 

Either way, the overall pace, style and creativity make this game one of my favourites. Whilst it's got a couple of 'could be better's to it, the list is very small. The positives of this game far outweigh the negatives and I intend on frittering away even more hours of my life on House Flipper 2 when it's released. Can't recommend this game highly enough. <3

I like the idea of it; but to be honest, there are far too many gliches. I find that it's becoming more and more frustrating with each update I download. The furniture in any given room with ghost out (like it does when placing floor tiles) colors don't match on countertops even though the same color options were chosen.  Sometimes when i set a lamp on the floor to move a table or shelf, the lamp disappears when i try to pick it back up which results in me having to purchase it again. The prices are generally cheap on those things, so it's no big loss, but it is annoying. My biggest thing though is that despite being from HGTV, there are barely any measurements or thought put into how something fits into a space. The sims build mode does better at that... and that's truely saying something since a lot of us know the monstrosity that is the sim4 build mode. If you like designing, i would recommend given some bug fixes.
EDIT to add: Why am a I constantly having to update this thing for DLC I don't have? I haven't played in a while but I keep all my games up to date. When i look on the page it's for DLC I've yet to purchase. What a waste of space. I'm considering deleting.

This game.... has taken control of my life ahaha. In a good way!! It's an awesome game to unwind and play after work or school. I have about 230+ hours (as of writing this review) and I still have a ton of more houses I can flip (I haven't even flipped all of them yet!). I love the customization of this game. Don't like cockroaches? No problem! You can switch it to broken glass. Don't want manly hands? No problem! You can change your hands to zombie hands, robot hands, farmer hands, etc! Don't want to crap your pants while designing a "haunted" Halloween house? No problem! The game gives you the option to turn off spooky effects, which is really nice! Also, this game has really cool "Easter-egg" houses from pop-culture TV shows/movies, interesting job stories, and fun mystery/crime styled houses you can clean and flip. 

I currently own all the DLCs and I have to say, if you were going to just buy 1, I would 100% buy the Gardening DLC. This allows you to cut the grass, cut down trees, plant flowers, trees and various bushes outside, put furniture outside, and etc. The "flip" feels more complete when the house is fully done (both outside and inside). Also, if your outdoor area fits one of the "Outdoor themes" for the gardening contest, it can substantially increase the value of the house, which means more money to design the homes of your dreams! (There are tips online on how you can score great on these contests). If you were going to buy a second DLC, I would recommend the Farming DLC. Even though there are still some bugs since it's new, this allows you to build extensions to a select number of homes, build homes from scratch, and you can unlock tools that will decrease time consuming tasks/ make your life easier, such as the grappling hook, chainsaw, paint gun (for outdoor painting) and etc.

However, the more DLCs you buy, the more cool houses and jobs you can flip and fix up, which is super nice. The Luxury DLC, Pet DLC and Farming DLC have jobs that have an associated story with voice acting, which is cool! The HGTV DLC has  jobs where you are presented with various choices to either save money, or spend a little more to fix up something in particular during the flip. I have played all the jobs in all the DLCs, and they have kept me busy for hours, especially the huge houses. However, I recommend waiting to get the DLCs on sale if you can (That's what I did).

If I had to say something negative about this game, it would be about the amount of buyers available. The way you make the most money is fitting the needs of a particular buyer. For example, some buyers will only want one bedroom, one bathroom, an office, etc. While other buyers will want specific types of rooms (There's guides on Wiki and online for assistance), multiple bedrooms, multiple bathrooms, etc. At first, it's fun trying to get all the achievements and getting all the buyers to buy at least one of the houses you have designed. But after selling a few houses to the same buyers over and over again, it can get repetitive. I hope they will either add more buyers in the future, or add this in the sequel to this game (House Flipper 2). 

Also, something I wish I knew before playing is the Workshop tab. Once you buy and install the game, you can unlock hundreds of amazing community designed furniture, accessories, decorations etc. It's a game changer... and I wish I knew about it in the start! Make sure you check it out, and grab some awesome designs! 

If you like renovating, cleaning, designing and having fun.. you will love this game. But be warned...you will be hooked!

So why do I not recommend this game despite the long hours I've played and will continue to do so? Simple - this game is my visual stim. Now that EA has ducked up Origin and I can't get Sim 4's building mode, this is my only way to get an anonymous building fix (and honestly Sims does a better job and it's only half the game).

Quiet simply, this game is exorbitantly overpriced.  But wait, you say - it's only $15, you say. Yeah, well - this game is downright unplayable without almost ALL of the pricey DLC so appearances are definitely deceiving on this one. 

I will say the game isn't bad - it's a lot of fun if you like building sims - but the price tag makes it decidedly NOT worth it. Game and controls are SUPER buggy and all the DLC are expensive add-on that should have been in the base game. Don't want the garden to look like shit? Money please. Want to build add-ons to the property? Money please. Want to change roof color or paint the outside of the house? Money please. I mean it's ridiculous. There are some nice extra furniture and features with the DLC, sure - but they're buggy, don't always stack well with the base game and it is really just such a bitter pill at $15 for each subpar DLC on top of the game. If you want a fleshed out game and try to get all useful functions when it's not on sale, that's about 60+ bucks just from DLC shit. 

Are some games work the heavy price tag? Sure. Is this game one of them? Duck no. 

If you can get this during the summer sale or something at an EXTREME discount (no more than $20 with DLC) then yeah, probably worth it. Current price tag? Definitely not. At the end of the day, I like this game and the hefty price tag was worth it to me (look at my play hours) but I need a certain amount of mindless visual stimming and this is it for me. 

For what it is, few players are going to find worth in the game at this price - especially when you could go get Tears of the Kingdom or some other open world beauty for a little bit LESS money.

This is a fun and really well-made game! Really great to play when I need to relax or clam down. Some parts are more fun then others (for example, I love painting the walls and decorating the house). I do have a few suggestions however. 
1: Ability to make renovations to the houses (ie. add rooms on, create a basement, create a garage, add other entrances, add a bunker)
2: More items to the buying menu (there is already A LOT of different items to chose from, but after 7 or 8 houses, you start to lack variety) New furniture, some vehicles, more electronic choices, more little nick-nack decorations, etc.
3: The ability to mix paint colours would be pretty cool.
4: (Corresponds with suggestion 1) Ability to connect basement to a bunker would definitely be a feature I would use frequently.

I truly enjoy this game, in fact i like it so much that I've done every job. I just have the regular market houses left!
although I do think that there should be some stuff added to the dlcs and the base game.

There's no bugs in the base game but I think there should be a couple more beds or bedroom items specifically for younger kids because I think the game lacks good looking beds for kids and younger kids like babies. 

I think the game would greatly benefit from maybe a dlc that added more houses but they're related more to kids whether the parents are expecting or welcoming their kids home from college, this dlc can help to introduce new things like putting together cribs and other various pieces of furniture, this dlc can also help introduce things like new toys and other items!

DLC reviews - 
pets - 
I started out with the pets dlc and I think it's a great one to start with, however there are definitely some things that need to be added. 
There's a good amount of dog breeds but there should definitely be more, I think there should be more breeds such as pitbulls, bulldogs, boxers, etc

I've seen many good cat breeds, but they should add more breeds like exotics, bobtails and calicos!!

the rodents and fish are good enough but I'm personally not happy with the reptiles or birds, I think the game would definitely benefit from having different kinds of reptiles such as beardies, ball pythons, geckos, etc. The parrots are a huge disappointment because there should be different breeds such as budgies, lovebirds, macaws, etc

overall I do like this dlc but they should also add different bird cages, reptile tanks, and different fish tanks as well as a few new pet items like toys and beds.

Garden dlc - 
I love this dlc! it's so fun, but it needs a few things added to it!

I think there should be a few new plants, whether they're indoor or outdoor plants. I also believe that there should be new outdoor plants such as shaped bushes or flowers. All of the outdoor items are good, I like the fact that you have to assemble almost all of the items. 

I also think that they should add a jobs map like with the other dlcs just so we can get to know some new characters. If that's not possible though it would b nice to see some new jobs!

HGTV dlc - 
I'm absolutely in LOVE with this dlc, the best feature of this dlc is when you're doing some of the jobs the owners will change what they want done with the house. At first it was stressful but then I started to like it because I think it makes the game more realistic. 

Overall the only thing I have to say about this dlc is i wish it had more jobs!! or even another jobs map for it!!

luxury dlc - 
i also LOVE this dlc, the best feature of this dlc is refurbishing the furniture! it's so fun! I wish there were more refurbishing opportunities though!

overall this one is awesome too, I just wish there were more houses or properties, but mainly houses!!

Farm dlc - 
with the farm dlc being so new, I don't expect it to be perfect but there should definitely be some things added, mainly with the animals! The house building feature is awesome! the house decor is great too! 

The problem with the animals is VARIETY!!!

I love the different horses but I think the game would greatly benefit from different breeds that are clearly different from each other. 

The chickens are so cute but I think they're bland!! the dlc would greatly benefit from different breeds such as silkies, plymouth rocks, etc

The pigs and the cows look great but I don't think there should be different breeds but there should definitely be different colorations and there should be bulls, male pigs, and calves should be available to buy as well!!

The sheep, goats, and alpacas are super cute, but there should be males, babies for sale, and different colors!! there should be llamas too but they should be paired in with the alpacas too

I think the dlc would greatly benefit from more animal items being added like things for the goats to climb on, horse toys or items, and other various animal enrichment items!!

overall I love this game and I think it's very fun especially if some of the fan suggestions are added and I would definitely recommend it to everyone, especially some of my favorite DLCS!!!

House Flipper is a popular simulation game that allows players to renovate and decorate houses for profit. While the game offers an enjoyable experience and can be a great way to pass the time, it is true that the gameplay can become repetitive if players consistently engage in the same activities at every house. Here's an explanation of why House Flipper can be a fun game but may feel repetitive after a while:

Initial Enjoyment: When players first start playing House Flipper, there is a sense of excitement and satisfaction in transforming rundown properties into beautiful homes. The game offers a wide range of tasks, such as cleaning, painting, and furnishing, which can be engaging and rewarding initially.

Variety of Houses: House Flipper features a variety of houses with different sizes, layouts, and conditions. This diversity allows players to experience various renovation challenges and creative opportunities. Initially, exploring and discovering new houses can keep the gameplay fresh and interesting.

Repetition of Tasks: As players progress and complete more houses, they may find themselves performing similar tasks repeatedly. This repetition can lead to a sense of monotony and make the gameplay feel less exciting and engaging over time. When players find themselves doing the same activities at every house, the game can lose some of its initial appeal.

Limited Depth and Variety: While House Flipper offers a range of activities and customization options, some players may feel that the game lacks depth and variety in the long run. The core gameplay loop of cleaning, renovating, and selling houses can become predictable, especially for those seeking more complex challenges or greater depth in the simulation aspect.

To mitigate the feeling of repetition, House Flipper provides periodic updates and DLCs, introducing new houses, items, and features to expand the gameplay experience. Additionally, players can experiment with different renovation styles, explore creative designs, and set personal goals to keep the experience fresh and engaging.

In conclusion, House Flipper is a fun game that can be enjoyed as a means to pass the time and indulge in virtual home renovation. However, it is not uncommon for players to find the gameplay repetitive after a while, particularly if they continue to engage in the same tasks at every house. Despite this, periodic updates and personal creativity can help mitigate the feeling of repetition and keep the game enjoyable for those who appreciate the simulation and creative aspects of home renovation.

It's a fun and chill game to play. The jobs are easy, and usually the game is specific about what to do. I really enjoy getting to buy houses and renovate them to my liking, however long I want to take on it. My only real gripes are the music and glitchy controls. The music gets old fast, but it's easy enough to turn off the music and listen to your own music. There are things that glitch in/out of eachother, and sometimes things simply won't work. That's to be expected from an older game with a sequel coming though. Overall, a good game and something to spend hours on.

Finally, I don't have to play Fallout 4 any more, because this game is 90% of what I spent my 400 hours in that game doing: cleaning up trash and making my settlement look nice. Had to install mods there in order to clean up ALL the trash and get buildings that actually look like they're not made of rotting timbers, and the physics were always janky anyway on the non-flat ground. None of that is a problem here! Interface is intuitive, and I'm enjoying leveling up my skills to do things better as I go.

Also, I live in California, and the two hours I've spent in this game's tutorial so far is the most I've seen radiators in my entire life. Are they really this common in other parts of the country? Places that actually build houses out of bricks, I guess. Luckily, the buyers don't seem to actually care whether there are radiators or not, so I just sell them when flipping a house and stop thinking about it.

I wish the game made it easier to find furniture and other things I'm looking for in the shop. Let me mark favorite items, or hide things I never want to use ever. Give items tags so I know what the buyers consider "modern" vs "old fashioned" and let me search and filter for those!

I also wish there was some better help for aligning objects with walls or other objects. It's especially frustrating when I'm trying to do something like making sure the dining table is centered under the ceiling lamp -- I can't see the lamp when I'm moving the table, and vice versa. A way to lock on to a measurement in order to align the edges as is standard in actual design software would go a long way. And why is it so hard to line furniture up with walls? I shouldn't even be able to preview an item passing through a wall. I know the game can do it because some of the new expansion items do this well! Just make it apply to all of the base game items too!

And I'm still not sure what exactly I'm accomplishing when installing a washer. (No dryers!) I unscrew a back panel so I can unscrew some larger screws that were already fully accessible, and then I screw the back panel back on??

I have too many hours in this game for me to start over so I just won't play until I have A DOOR on my house.

House Flipper is a unique and exciting game that offers a refreshing break from traditional video games. In this game, you play the role of a home renovation expert, taking on different houses and restoring them to their former glory.

One of the things I appreciate about House Flipper is the attention to detail in the design and renovation process. You have access to a wide range of tools and equipment, allowing you to fix everything from leaky pipes to broken walls. The game even offers a decorating mode, where you can choose from various furniture and decor options to make the house your own.

Another great feature of House Flipper is the freedom it gives players to customize their gameplay experience. You can choose which houses to renovate, which upgrades to prioritize, and how much time to spend on each project. This allows you to tailor the game to your preferences and create a unique experience every time you play.

The graphics in House Flipper are also impressive, with detailed textures and realistic lighting effects that make the houses feel like real homes. The game's sound design is also well-done, with realistic sound effects that add to the overall immersion.

But what sets House Flipper apart from other games is the sense of satisfaction that comes with restoring a house to its former glory. Seeing the transformation from a run-down, neglected home to a beautifully renovated masterpiece is incredibly rewarding.

In conclusion, House Flipper is an excellent game that offers a fun and unique experience. Its attention to detail, freedom of customization, and sense of satisfaction make it a game worth trying for anyone who enjoys simulation and renovation games. If you are looking for a break from traditional video games and want to unleash your inner home renovation expert, House Flipper is the perfect game for you.

Edit: I wanted to add something now that I played all DLCs and I'm at 200 hours, when you "beat" the game, that is you complete all jobs and sell all houses once, all houses become permanently available and you can buy and sell them as many times as you want - multiple of the same (there are 90 houses), replayability is insane!

Also something about the devs. The last DLC (Farm) was very bugged at release, lots of problems, but devs reacted beautifully IMO, they openly apologized and released a lot of fixes very quickly, and are still doing do, while communicating with the playerbase. This shows they really care about their game and the players, it's so rare nowadays to find devs invested in their work instead of caring only about money, they deserve to be supported.

is an enjoyable game that offers a unique and satisfying experience for those interested in home renovation. However, it may not be for everyone due to its repetitive nature.

House Flipper is a game where you have to buy a house from the worst houses to the best depending on how much money you have. you can build the interior of the house as you wish you can paint it, build your room, living room, kitchen, etc. And then sell it for quite a lot of money and earn money, but you can also earn money with missions. 

I personally liked this game and I hope you will like it you too.

I will recommend the game, only for the reason that I believe this game is great for anyone, however, as someone with ADHD in video games, it is a massive headache to align objects on the ceiling, put down gravel in a straight line without it moving an inch to the right or left, and the worst one being given an object limiter on painting the walls. The "A Colorful Fiesta" was a nightmare, I couldn't get the walls painted how I wanted it and I know it's not my house, but if the customer wanted it done a specific way I should've been given a blueprint on how they wanted it colored, been stuck going from "39/40" to "49/50" with it looking disgusting. Not gonna lie, a lot of these designs to limit creativity has turned me off of this game multiple times, but after a couple of months I come back until something like that happens again.

I have some advice for new players; DON'T get the dlc. At least, not immediately. You see, the game allows you to buy back and decorate houses as much as you want. There's just one condition; you have to have completed ALL missions and flipped ALL houses. .

Obviously, this is much easier to do if you only have the base game, where you only have to worry about 30 or so houses (and their associated missions). This becomes a LOT harder if you try to do this with all DLC (including the free DLC) on your account.] The DLC adds around 47-50 ADDITIONAL houses to flip (and associated missions), so that's more than double your workload to get through just to get the ability to buy back houses. 

I'm close to 100 hours and I STILL haven't finished through the DLC in order to unlock buy back. I really miss some of the houses I already sold, but there's nothing I can do to see them again until I finish my task of completing all the DLCs.
I decided I was going to hold off on the farm dlc until I finished with what I got, so I can unlock buyback before adding all those additional missions and houses.   That ended up working in my favor, I think, because it seems that the farm dlc has got it's fair share of problems there.   

So this is just a head's up; don't be like me. Only work on the base game first and ignore all the DLCs until you finished it. The ability to buy back houses whenever you want is not one to be taken lightly, and will help you immensely. Especially if love the design aspect of it, and want to design the same houses again and again. 

And I think, in general, it's a good idea anyways to just buy the base game first. That way, if it turns out you don't like it (but somehow made it past Steam's refund timeline), you haven't lost as much. Remember, you can always go back and buy the bundle for the discounted price even if you own some of the items.

P.S. Also, if you like making stripes or patterns with different paints, DO NOT get the "paint two walls at once" line of perks.  It's incredibly annoying when you want to make alternating stripes of paint. I wish they made it work like building walls (and laying tiles), where you simple use the scroll wheel to control whether you make one wall or two (or more).  And the unfortunate part is, you cannot disable perks once you've gotten them.

My favorite simulator video game. If I weren't a video game producer, I would be an interior designer. Developed by Empyrean and released in 2018, in this game, we can remodel, clean, disinfect, sell, and buy houses on demand.

The game has a wide variety of tools and customization options so that players can create unique and personalized designs. They can also perform repair and maintenance work for clients who need help in their homes. These jobs range from garden cleaning to appliance installation.

If you've watched many hours of "Property Brothers," you'll be able to enjoy transforming properties into beautiful homes as much as I do.

I have a love for interior decorating and games such as The Sims and Animal Crossing where a big chunk of game play is focused on that task is heavily loved by me. That being said, this game where the sole purpose is to flip houses and decorate them is obviously another top game for myself with the amount of hours I have put into it. 

My only complaint with the game is not enough decor items- coming from a Sims player who uses custom content (lol). And mounting things is kind of annoying but I can look past that. That being said, this game is very therapeutic for me and I would recommend it to anyone who wants that casual and relaxing type of game and also loves decorating as much as I do.

I regret buying GARDEN FLIPPER.  I would never have bought it in its current state and if they had offered me this for free, I would have said no.

It has so many problems.  The major ones being that you earn a grass-cutter which is like someone asking you to clean your whole house with a toothbrush.  The gardens are huge, great you say until after spending hours mowing the lawn, you exit the game only to find that the grass has grown back.  This defeats the whole object of this game which is to design a really nice garden which you cannot do with a continuously unmowed and unweeded garden.

I had to sell the house that I spent 22 hrs working on for a loss because there was no point in trying to continue.

My office furniture was replaced with different colours.

I then get the update only to find that all the maxed out gardening perks I had earned, were gone.  I have quite a few of the gardening achievements unlocked, but all the perks are gone.

A million pounds was taken from my account.   I could go on.

Someone knew that this game was not ready which is why it was offered at a discounted price. I would rather have paid a little more for a decent game.  Empyrean should be ashamed.

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME AS IT IS NOT READY  in fact I have posted that I would like a refund and that I would like to make a complaint.

UPDATE: It's been a while since I first reviewed Garden Flipper. At the time I asked for, and got a refund. I waited over a year until the majority of bugs were fixed, and then re-purchased it.

I am happy to say that I can now give a more positive review of this DLC.
The tools that you use to garden with, the trimmer and the mower have drastically improved in performance. It is now quick and easy to mow your garden, which stays mowed.
There's a good selection of flowers, plants, outdoor furniture and structures.
Creating decent gardens is one of my favourite parts of House Flipper, and I thoroughly enjoy taking part in the garden competitions, of which I might add,  I make a lot of money as you can boost your profits up to 50% of your house property if you gain enough points.

So, yes I do recommend Garden Flipper, because when this game works, it is brilliant and gives me hours of enjoyment.

However, I do recommend to anyone buying any DLC to make a separate back-up of the game. { I keep mine on a usb}. I've had to re-start from scratch at least 3 times now, because I've lost all progress. So, just bear this in mind.

Well I have loved this game for years and I love that they have added a farming aspect to the game. HOWEVER, there are real difficulties with some things now. Building a greenhouse properly is very difficult as you have no way of planning out what size of panels you need beforehand. The only thing you can do is play with it and rebuild and rebuild until you get it. Also some of the farm jobs are quite tricky if you don't put a piece exactly where it's supposed to be then you don't get paid for it. I wish the developers would make it clearer where things need to go exactly. As well, I have been frustrated with this aspect for years. In real life, if someone asks you to redecorate their place they tell you exactly where they want things placed. As it is you can just pile on the items in the center of the room and still get paid for it. That doesn't make sense. 

It's still a very fun game though if you can get past some of the frustrations.

If you really love zen, decorating, or are a bit ocd and need to have a clean house even if its only pretend, this is for you. With all the DLC's and updates the amount of decorations, options, colors, and choices has grown so much! I only wish they had a detailed guide, because there are things the customers like or the contests require that are not obvious. The items aren't exactly straight forward in what they 'count' as and it's not clear what everyone wants and if items are solely decorational or if they affect anything, but even with that, it's truly an enjoyable game. I blame Markiplier for ever finding out it existed. If he hadn't stopped after one game I wouldn't have gone crazy with curiosity. It's a lovely game and SO MUCH EFFORT has been put into it.

This game is an addictive creative outlet. It's a great way to de-stress. I have really liked all of the dlc's as well.

The perfect game for everyone who always enjoyed building and decorating houses in The Sims the most! Also VERY comitted developers, regular free additional content und a great user community who fills the workshop with new stuff constantly :).

One of the best games I played in the last 2 years! Great mechanics, excellent graphics, and an exciting narrative. Each of the DLCs brings more and more engaging content, quests, and objects. 

You can use this game not only for good time-spending but with newly added mechanics you can now build the house of your dream or become an interior designer of your own house or flat to realize it in real life afterward! And the key thing - you are able to interact with all the switches, furniture, gadgets, etc. you are placing to see how it gonna work and look in real life!

You can now recreate houses from other games, like CJ`s house from GTA San Andreas, Michael or Franklin`s house from GTA V, or any other games! No limits to your fantasies! 
I have never gotten bored in this game, especially after adding pets that you can interact with and have a companion with you there in the quests) 

It is still exciting to pass all the quests a few times, to achieve more interesting and each time different results with new mechanics, skills, and experiences you gained during the gameplay.  I'm using the game both for relaxation and inspiration! This is my top 10 for life and top 1 for this year!

Special thanks to the developers for the qualitative Ukrainian language! It is an extremely nice feeling to play my favorite game in my native language! Also, when my mom borrows my PC when she comes to visit me, she can play this game and have fun without knowing English, which is convenient and pleasant! 

Thanks again! Big fan! Waiting for new DLCs and the House Flipper 2 (wishlisted). 

💙💛🇺🇦🫶

This game is awesome!! I wish I had known about it sooner, but better late than never. I often find myself looking at the clock and saying to myself, "hmmm, 8pm. I'll don one more thing then go to bed.", and the next thing I know it's 2:30 in the morning LOL I used to do ceramic tile installations for a living. I so love construction and design. This game fills all those needs and the gardening is a major plus! Also, chances are if you can't find an item you are looking for in particular, just check the workshop. You'll find something in there 99% of the time, and sometimes find something even better than what you were thinking. I can't put this game down. 100% fun!!

I don't usually leave negative reviews. In this case I've have played this game for 24 hours. The biggest issue I have is that items do not stack. I'm doing a job that wants towels and candles placed and none of the existing furniture in the room will allow the items to be placed on them. I can only put the items on the floor. I can't continue to put hours into a game with such limitations. I've watch YT hints-n-tricks they come up with very tedious solutions of stacking books, putting the item on the book and then selling the books out from under so the item drops down. That is just stupid.  This game will get no more of my time.

A little monotonous sometimes.  The store inventory could be MUCH better organized.  The chicken coop door closes so the chickens can't get in to lay eggs.  Either keep opening it manually or deal with eggs in the yard. The furnishings and decor need a serious update.   The list goes on........
Yes, it's a good game and I recommend it.  Just be aware that it needs a lot of work.

With the Farm DLC it's definitely a little buggy, however the Devs have been quick to roll out hotfixes to help with that. The base game is pretty fun tho. Even without DLCs you can do quite a lot, but some people may feel restricted by not being able to change the outer walls. This is House Flipper, not Build a House though, and I find the restrictions to be a part of the fun. Overall I highly recommend buying the Gardening DLC if you're only going to buy one DLC, since it allows you to mow the lawn, and it kinda feels like getting to be able to an extra house per property.
